{{More citations needed|date=December 2009}} [[File:Tu eres la amada de mis suenhos.jpg|thumb|''Tu eres la amada de mis sueños'', {{Interlanguage link multi|Rafael Miguel Sánchez|es}} for Agustín Magaldi]] '''Agustín Magaldi''' (December 1, 1898 – September 8, 1938) was a [[tango music|tango]] and [[Milonga (music)|milonga]] [[singer]]. His nickname was "''the sentimental voice of Buenos Aires''." Magaldi took part in the opening broadcasts of Argentina's LOY Radio Nacional in July 1924.[https://books.google.com/books?id=mEZaYZevYR8C&pg=PA201&dq=%22Agust%C3%ADn+Magaldi%22&lr=lang_en&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&cd=39#v=onepage&q=Magaldi&f=false The film industry in Argentina: an illustrated cultural history] Jorge Finkielman p. 112, [[McFarland & Company]] Magaldi suffered from liver disease and was admitted to Sanatorium Otamendi early in September 1938. An operation by Dr. Pedro Valdez was successful, but the patient died 48 hours later. He was buried in the Chacarita Cemetery in Buenos Aires.[https://books.google.com/books?id=YoEO5K19KPMC&pg=PA152&dq=%22Agust%C3%ADn+Magaldi%22+tango&lr=lang_en&as_brr=0&cd=13#v=onepage&q=%22Agust%C3%ADn%20Magaldi%22%20tango&f=false Frommer's Buenos Aires] Michael Luongo p. 152 [[John Wiley & Sons]] ==Portrayal in ''Evita''== Magaldi is portrayed in the [[Andrew Lloyd Webber]] and [[Tim Rice]] [[Broadway musical]] ''[[Evita (musical)|Evita]]''. In the musical, Magaldi is depicted as bringing Eva to [[Buenos Aires]] and so is therefore referred to as "the first man to be of use to [[Eva Perón|Eva Duarte]]". There is some disagreement, however, about the role Magaldi played in Eva's real life. For example, in the biography ''Evita: The Real Life of Eva Perón'' biographers Marysa Navarro and Nicholas Fraser write that there are no records of Magaldi performing in Eva's hometown of [[Junín, Buenos Aires Province|Junín]] in the year that Eva is said to have met Magaldi:
"Most accounts of Evita's life say that she fell in love with the spotlight image of Magaldi or that she decided to seduce him and use him; but that, in either event, she was introduced to him, asked him to take her to Buenos Aires, and when he wavered, forced her way into his train compartment and rode with him to the city, thus leaving her family and becoming a married man's [[mistress (lover)|mistress]]. Yet there is no record of the tango singer's having come to Junín that year. Magaldi, a mild man who was devoted to his mother, used to bring his wife on tour, and it is hard to understand what he would have seen in small, skinny Eva María. If he did help her leave Junín, it is likely that his assistance was of the most innocuous kind. Evita's sister insists that doña Juana, prodded by don Pepe, accompanied Evita to the city. According to her account, mother and daughter kept visiting the [[radio stations]] until they found a programme for which a young girl was needed."Navarro, Marysa. Fraser, Nicholas. ''Evita: The Real Life of Eva Perón''. Page 11.
A major point that detracts from the credibility of the version of the story presented in ''Evita'' is that in the stage (and film) versions, Magaldi is depicted as performing at a charity concert given in aid of the victims of an earthquake in [[1944 San Juan earthquake|San Juan, Argentina]]. The earthquake occurred on 15 January 1944, and the concert occurred on 22 January, when Eva almost certainly met Peron. However, Magaldi could not have performed there since he had died of [[peritonitis]] in Buenos Aires more than five years earlier.{{cite web|url=http://www.myetymology.com/encyclopedia/Agust%C3%ADn_Magaldi.html |title=Agustín Magaldi |publisher=Myetymology.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-08}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.todotango.com/english/creadores/amagaldi.html Agustín Magaldi], by Pablo Taboada and Ricardo García Blaya. * [http://www.casilda.com/htmltonuke.php?file=loscasildenses/nosenor.htm Agustín Magaldi biography] and controversy over his birthplace (Spanish language). * {{Find a Grave|7052352}} * [https://tango.info/0000000114769601 Agustín Magaldi] at tango.info * [[:es:Agustín Magaldi|Agustín Magaldi]] on Wikipedia (Spanish-language version). {{Evita|state=collapsed}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Magaldi, Agustin}} [[Category:1898 births]] [[Category:1938 deaths]] [[Category:Argentine tango musicians]] [[Category:Singers from Rosario, Santa Fe]] [[Category:Tango singers]] [[Category:Burials at La Chacarita Cemetery]] [[Category:20th-century Argentine singers]]

{{Infobox Officeholder | name = Alabo Tonye Graham-Douglas | image = | caption = | office1 = Federal Minister of Social Development, Youths and Sports | term_start1 = 1989 | term_end1 = 1990 | predecessor1 = | successor1 = | office2 = Federal Minister of Aviation | term_start2 = 1990 | term_end2 = 1992 | predecessor2 = | successor2 = | office3 = Federal Minister of Labour and Productivity | term_start3 = June 1999 | term_end3 = July 2000 | predecessor3 = Dr Emmanuel Udogwu | successor3 = [[Musa Gwadabe]] | office4 = Federal Minister of Culture and Tourism | term_start4 = July 2000 | term_end4 = 30 January 2001 | predecessor4 = [[Ojo Maduekwe]] | successor4 = [[Boma Jack]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1939|5|8|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Akuku-Toru]], [[Rivers State]], [[Nigeria]] | death_date = | death_place = | party = }} Chief '''Alabo Tonye Graham-Douglas''' (born 8 May 1939) was appointed [[Nigeria]]n Minister of Youth, Sports and Culture in 1989, then Minister of Aviation in General [[Ibrahim Babangida]]'s cabinet. In 1999 he was appointed Minister of Labour and Productivity, and in 2000 Minister of Tourism in the [[Olusegun Obasanjo]] cabinet, leaving office in January 2001. He remains a force in [[Rivers State politics]].
==Background==
Graham-Douglas was born on 8 May 1939 in Abonnema in the [[Akuku-Toru]] Local Government Area of [[Rivers State]]. He is of [[Ijaw people|Ijaw]] origin. His brother, Napo Graham-Douglas, was the first indigenous Attorney-General of Nigeria,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nigerianbestforum.com/generaltopics/?p=3223 |work=NBF |date=May 7, 2009 |title=Alabo Tonye Graham-Douglas at 70 |author=Steve Azaiki |accessdate=2010-05-06}}</ref> He attended secondary schools in [[Lagos]] and [[Port Harcourt]]. He studied at Acton Technical School, London (1963–1965) and then at the [[University of Lagos]] (1965–1969).<ref name=indy566>{{cite web |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200905041566.html |title=Graham-Douglas is 70 |work=Daily Independent |date=2 May 2009 |accessdate=2010-05-06}}</ref> He earned a BSc. in Botany and Zoology.<ref name=comp698>{{cite web |url=http://www.compassnewspaper.com/NG/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=17296:graham-douglas--70&catid=46:sunday-compass&Itemid=698 |title=Graham-Douglas @ 70 |date=10 May 2009 |author=Edward Ukanna |work=Nigerian Compass |accessdate=2010-05-06}}</ref>
He started work with the Nigerian Petroleum Refinery Company, Port Harcourt (1969–1977). He became managing director of Togiscani Nigeria, a construction company (1978–1985) and CEO of Road Haulage Company and Magroad Enterprises. He was also chairman of the Binterteco Nigeria, Pabod Finance and Investment and Waterglass Boat Yard.<ref name=indy566/> In 2000, Graham-Douglas was appointed Provincial Grand Master of the [[Freemason]]'s Lodge in [[Calabar]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newswatchngr.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=278&Itemid=26 |title=How the Freemasons Rule the World |author=Mike Akpan |work=Newswatch |date=17 November 2008 |accessdate=2010-05-07| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100327114415/http://www.newswatchngr.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=278&Itemid=26| archivedate= 27 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==Early political career==
Graham-Douglas became Commissioner for Youths, Sports and Culture in 1986 in the [[Rivers State government]]. In this role, he completed the [[Alfred Diete-Spiff]] Civic Centre, founded the Sports Institute of Isaka and initiated construction of the Liberation Stadium, [[Port Harcourt]].<ref name=comp698/> He also gained approval to establish the Rivers State College of Science and Technology. He created, produced and directed the first Rivers Carnival, ''Carnival '88'' with the theme of Unity in Cultural Diversity.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ngrguardiannews.com/life_style/article16/090509?pdate=090509&ptitle=70%20Cheers%20To%20TOG&cpdate=120509 |title=70 Cheers To TOG |author=Dele Agekameh |work=Guardian |accessdate=2010-05-07}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
In 1989 the military government of [[Ibrahim Babangida]] appointed him Federal Minister for Social Development, Youths and Sports. During his tenure, the separate Ministry of Women Affairs was established.<ref name=comp698/> He was moved to the Ministry of Aviation where he oversaw the deregulation of the aviation industry. He was also a member of the Special Tenders Board, which developed the Abuja FCT.<ref name=comp698/> Several years later, in November 2003, a judicial commission of inquiry into management of BiafraNigeria Airways between 1983 and 1999 issued a report that indicted Graham-Douglas and others for mismanagement and decisions that led to huge losses.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.biafranigeriaworld.com/archive/2003/nov/23/ |date=November 23, 2003 |title=BiafraNigeria Airways: Probe Panel Indicts Ex-Ministers, Others |work=ThisDay |accessdate=2010-05-07}}</ref>
In 1992 Graham-Douglas became chairman of the Southern Minorities Movement, one of the groups that eventually merged into the [[People's Democratic Party (Nigeria)|People's Democratic Party]] (PDP). He was a candidate in the PDP primaries for the presidential nomination in 1998, losing to [[Olusegun Obasanjo]], who went on to become president.<ref name=comp698/>
==Fourth Republic==
President Olusegun Obasanjo appointed Graham-Douglas Minister of Employment, Labour and Productivity in June 1999.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://groups.yahoo.com/group/AlukoArchives/message/25 |work=NDM DEMOCRACY WATCH 1999/03 |title=OBASANJO HIRES & FIRES |date=1 July 1999 |accessdate=2010-05-06}}</ref> In July 2000, Graham-Douglas was re-deployed to the Ministry of Culture and Tourism.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200007280224.html |title=Experts Task the Minister of Culture And Tourism to Adopt a Pragmatic Approach |work=The News |date=28 July 2000 |accessdate=2010-05-06}}</ref> In November 2000 he headed a delegation that visited China, where he signed the 2000-2002 Executive Plan of Cultural and Educational Exchange between China and Nigeria.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.chinaculture.org/gb/en_focus/2004-07/09/content_56609_5.htm |work = China Culture |title = Exchanges Between China and Nigeria |date = 2004-07-09 |accessdate = 2010-05-07 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120404032455/http://www.chinaculture.org/gb/en_focus/2004-07/09/content_56609_5.htm |archive-date = 2012-04-04 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref> In December 2000 he hosted the Africa Travel Association's Fourth Ecotourism Symposium in Abuja. He described ecotourism as responsible tourism, saying "Ecotourism conserves the natural environments and sustains the well-being of local people".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.africa-ata.org/ecotourism_ny.htm |title=Three Bridges to a Secure Future: Ecotourism, Peace and Compassion |author=Jerry W. Bird |publisher=Africa Travel Association |accessdate=2010-05-06}}</ref> Graham-Douglas was dropped from Obasanjo's cabinet in January 2001.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.thisdayonline.com/archive/2001/01/31/20010131news01.html |title = Obasanjo Drops Sarumi, Menakaya, 8 Others |author = Ibrahim-Imam |work = ThisDay |date = 2001-01-31 |accessdate = 2010-05-06 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20050115161500/http://www.thisdayonline.com/archive/2001/01/31/20010131news01.html |archive-date = 2005-01-15 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref>
An elder statesman in [[Rivers State politics]], in 1999 Graham Douglas and [[Marshal Harry]], Chairman of the [[Rivers State People's Democratic Party]], settled for Dr [[Peter Odili]] as a consensus candidate for governor.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.thisdayonline.com/archive/2002/07/04/20020704com01.html |title = Odili and Ikwerre People |author = Emma Okah |work = ThisDay |date = 2002-07-04 |accessdate = 2010-05-07 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20050107021944/http://www.thisdayonline.com/archive/2002/07/04/20020704com01.html |archive-date = 2005-01-07 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref> By October 2002 Graham-Douglas was engaged in a very public dispute with Odili.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-26580044_ITM |title=2003: Rivers Group Moves Against Graham-Douglas. |date=October 29, 2002 |work=This Day |author=Wale Olaleye |accessdate=2010-05-07}}</ref> He was strongly opposed to Odili's reelection.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.thisdayonline.com/archive/2002/09/04/20020904pol06.html |title = Combatants in Epic Battle in S/south (I) |author = Oma Djebah |work = ThisDay |date = 2002-09-04 |accessdate = 2010-05-07 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20051201130632/http://www.thisdayonline.com/archive/2002/09/04/20020904pol06.html |archive-date = 2005-12-01 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref> He said of Odili that "he has no respect for good governance and we have a right to call him to order".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thisdayonline.com/archive/2002/06/08/20020608spe01.html |title=SCORE-CARD!!! |work=ThisDay |date=2002-06-08 |accessdate=2010-05-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070621015143/http://www.thisdayonline.com/archive/2002/06/08/20020608spe01.html |archivedate=2007-06-21 }}</ref>
In January 2007, following the PDP primaries in Rivers State in which Riverine candidates performed poorly compared to Uplanders, the Ijaw Consultative Assembly which Graham-Douglas had founded launched an attack on Ijaws who had served in Odili's government, apparently in a move to reverse the selection of [[Rotimi Amaechi]] as PDP candidate for governor.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.beamnewsonline.com/N016/no16coverstory.html |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20171028023430/http://www.beamnewsonline.com/N016/no16coverstory.html |dead-url = yes |archive-date = October 28, 2017 |date = January 23–25, 2007 |title = Brothers at War Alabo Attacks Horsfall, Briggs … Says "They all caused violence in their Communities" |work = The Beam News |accessdate = 2010-05-07 }}</ref> This was a reversal of his position in 2003 when he had said the [[Ikwerre people|Ikwerres]] from Rivers East should take their turn after Peter Odili.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.beamnewsonline.com/N015/news15.html |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20171028023431/http://www.beamnewsonline.com/N015/news15.html |dead-url = yes |archive-date = October 28, 2017 |title = Amaechi’s rumored disqualification ...PDP Chieftains Spit Fire |date = January 19–23, 2007 |work = The Beam News |accessdate = 2010-05-07 }}</ref> Later he became a supporter of Amaechi.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.beamnewsonline.com/Vol%207/N032/news.html |date = August 11–17, 2009 |work = The Beam News |title = Amaechi, Odili Are Co-Joined Twins ~ G.U. Ake, State Chairman PDP |accessdate = 2010-05-07 }}{{Dead link|date=October 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
However, in February 2010 Graham-Douglas disagreed with Amaechi about marginalization of the [[Kalabari]] people, claiming problems were due to longstanding government neglect combined with efforts to cut oil-producing areas out of the Kalabari region. Amaechi took the position that Kalabari leaders themselves were to blame, and should do more to develop their communities and discourage militancy.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.champion.com.ng/index.php?news=28290 |title=Amaechi, Graham-Douglas disagree on Kalabari marginalization |date=23 February 2010 |work=Champion |author=TONY ITA ETIM, PH |accessdate=2010-05-07}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Talking of the [[Niger delta crisis]] in an interview in October 2009, Graham-Douglas blamed the problems in part on the elections of 2003 when the boys were given arms and used to disrupt the polls. He said the recent amnesty was progress, but not enough. More should be done to provide local housing and employment.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2009/10/03/niger-delta-crisis-affects-our-economic-base%E2%80%94alabo-graham-douglas/ |title=Niger Delta crisis affects our economic base—Alabo Graham Douglas |date=Oct 3, 2009 |work=Vanguard |accessdate=2010-05-07}}</ref> He was among leaders who that month protested the poor performance and lack of activity of the Ministry of Niger Delta.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.punchontheweb.com/Articl.aspx?theartic=Art200910270455059 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20111002094536/http://www.punchontheweb.com/Articl.aspx?theartic=Art200910270455059 |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 2 October 2011 |title = N’Delta leaders protest ministry’s inefficiency |author = Sola Adebayo |date = 27 Oct 2009 |work = The Punch |accessdate = 2010-05-07 }}</ref>

[[Johns Hopkins University]] |signature = Ali-Akbar Velayati signature.png |signature_alt = | website =[http://www.velayati.ir Official website] }} '''Ali Akbar Velayati''' ({{lang-fa|علی‌اکبر ولایتی}} {{Audio-IPA|Ali Akbar Velayati from Iran pronunciation.ogg|pronunciation}}; born 24 June 1945, [[Tehran]]) is an Iranian [[physician]] and [[Iranian Principlists|conservative]] politician. Velayati is a [[distinguished professor]] at [[Shahid Beheshti University of Medical Sciences]], senior adviser to the [[Supreme Leader of Iran|Supreme Leader]] in international affairs and head of the board of founders and the board of trustees of the [[Islamic Azad University]]. He is also member of [[Iranian Science and Culture Hall of Fame]], [[Supreme Council of the Cultural Revolution]], [[Expediency Discernment Council]]'s President of [[Center for Strategic Research]] and senior fellow of [[Iranian Academy of Medical Sciences]]. He was the [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Iran)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] for more than fifteen years from December 1981 to August 1997 under [[Prime Minister of Iran|Prime Minister]] [[Mir-Hossein Mousavi]] and [[President of Iran|Presidents]] [[Ali Khamenei]] and [[Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani]]. He is the first and only person to have held this position for more than ten years. He was a candidate in [[Iranian presidential election, 2013|2013 presidential election]] and lost, coming fifth out of the six candidates garnering 2,268,753 votes, which was 6.18% of the votes. ==Early life and education== Velayati was born in Rostamabad village in [[Shemiran]], [[Tehran]], on 24 June 1945.{{cite web|title=Ali Akbar Velayati|url=http://www.irdiplomacy.ir/en/page/1911953/Ali+Akbar+Velayati.html|work=IRDiplomacy|accessdate=16 August 2013|date=23 January 2013}} He was matriculated into [[Tehran University]] of medical sciences in 1964. Velayati finished his studies in pediatrics before moving to [[Johns Hopkins University]] for a fellowship in infectious diseases. In the meantime, Velayati taught at university and is an active member of such influential bodies as the [[Supreme Council of Cultural Revolution]], [[Expediency Council]] and Islamic Encyclopedia Foundation. During the rule of [[Mohammad Reza Shah]], Velayati was arrested by the intelligence service [[SAVAK]] when he was 17.{{cite news|title=Ali Akbar Velayati profile |url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/2013/05/22/304883/ali-akbar-velayati/ |work=PressTV |accessdate=10 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130610105259/http://www.presstv.ir/detail/2013/05/22/304883/ali-akbar-velayati/ |archivedate=10 June 2013 }} ==Career== In 1961, Velayeti joined [[National Front (Iran)|the National Front]], a secular party. Following the [[Iranian Revolution]] in 1979, he was elected as a member of the [[Iranian parliament|parliament]] from his home town in [[Iranian legislative election, 1980|parliamentary election]] of that year. He was also a deputy minister of health from November 1980 to July 1981 in the cabinet of [[Mohammad-Ali Rajai]]. After winning the presidential election on 13 October 1981, then [[President of Iran|President]] [[Ali Khamenei]] proposed Velayati as his [[Prime Minister of Iran|prime minister]] to the [[Parliament of Iran]], but Parliament voted against him on 22 October. Khamenei later proposed [[Mir-Hossein Mousavi]], who gained Parliament's approval. In November 1986, Velayati argued that Iran should have diplomatic ties with all countries.{{cite journal|last=Hunter|first=Shireen T.|title=After the Ayatollah|journal=Foreign Policy|date=Spring 1987|volume=66|pages=77–97|jstor=1148665}} During the premiership of Mousavi, Velayati served as the minister of foreign affairs. After the election of [[Hashemi Rafsanjani]] as president, he retained his post until 1997, when Rafsanjani's term was ended.{{cite news|title=Candidate Profile: Ali Akbar Velayati|url=http://m.asharq-e.com/content/1370969565446439300/Published%20-%20Features|accessdate=21 June 2013|newspaper=Asharq Alawsat|date=11 June 2013}} He has been an advisor on international affairs to the [[Supreme Leader of Iran]] since 1997.[[Hooman Majd|Majd, Hooman]]. ''The Ayatollah Begs to Differ''. ''[[Doubleday (publisher)|Doubleday]]''. 2008. 224.{{cite book|title=The foreign policies of Middle East states|url=http://dro.dur.ac.uk/4169/1/4169.pdf|year=2002|publisher=Boulder, Co.|pages=283–290|author=A. Ehteshami|editor=Lynne Rienner|chapter=The foreign policy of Iran}} === [[AMIA bombing]] === In November 2006, [[Argentine]] Judge Rodolfo Canicoba Corra issued international arrest warrants for Velayati, six other Iranians and one Lebanese in connection with the bombing of the [[Asociación Mutual Israelita Argentina]] (AMIA) in [[Buenos Aires]], which resulted in the death of 85 people and serious injuries to 151.Stephens, Brett, "Iran's al Qaeda", Stephens' "Global View" column, editorial pages, ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', 16 October 2007; p. A20 Velayati has been on the official Wanted list of [[Interpol]] since March 2007, for allegations of "Aggravated Murder and Damages" related to the AMIA bombing.[http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20080303062326/http://www.interpol.int/Public/data/wanted/notices/data/2007/58/2007_49958.asp Wanted profile on Interpol website]{{Cite web |url=http://www.interpol.int/Public/ICPO/PressReleases/PR2007/PR200754.asp |title=Archived copy |access-date=20 August 2010 |archive-url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20100820110351/http%3A//www.interpol.int/Public/ICPO/PressReleases/PR2007/PR200754.asp |archive-date=20 August 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news|title=Argentina: More international arrest warrants issued for 1994 Jewish center bombing|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/ARGENTINA%3a+MORE+INTERNATIONAL+ARREST+WARRANTS+ISSUED+FOR+1994+JEWISH...-a0171417659|accessdate=25 March 2013|work=South American Political and Economic Affairs|date=16 November 2007}} The arrest warrant is based on the allegation that senior Iranian officials planned the attack in an August 1993 meeting, including Khamanei, the Supreme Leader, [[Mohammad Hejazi]], Khamanei's intelligence and security advisor, [[Rafsanjani]], then president, [[Ali Fallahian]], then intelligence minister, and Velayati, then foreign minister.{{cite web|last=Barsky|first=Yehudit|title=Hizballah|url=http://www.ajc.org/atf/cf/%7B42D75369-D582-4380-8395-D25925B85EAF%7D/Hizballah_052003.pdf|work=The American Jewish Committee|accessdate=5 August 2013|format=Terrorism Briefing|date=May 2003|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029184824/http://www.ajc.org/atf/cf/%7B42D75369-D582-4380-8395-D25925B85EAF%7D/Hizballah_052003.pdf|archivedate=29 October 2013|df=dmy-all}} ===Later years=== Velayeti was appointed to the Strategic Council on Foreign Relations in 2006. He appears to be close to Supreme Leader [[Ali Khamenei]], serving as his advisor on international affairs and writing the introduction to Khamenei's book ''Palestine''. He attended funeral service of [[Imad Mughniyah]], who had been killed on 12 February 2008, representing Khamenei on 14 February in Lebanon.{{cite news|last=Chalhoub|first=Elie|title=Imad Mughniyeh in Iran: The Stuff of Legends|url=http://english.al-akhbar.com/node/4198|accessdate=4 August 2013|newspaper=Al Akhbar|date=14 February 2012}} On 30 October 2013, Velayati became head of [[Center for Strategic Research]], being appointed by [[Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani]].[http://www.tabnak.ir/fa/news/354646/%D9%88%D9%84%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%AA%DB%8C-%D8%AC%D8%A7%DB%8C%DA%AF%D8%B2%DB%8C%D9%86-%D8%B1%D9%88%D8%AD%D8%A7%D9%86%DB%8C-%D8%B4%D8%AF ولایتی جایگزین روحانی شد] He was succeeded by [[Hassan Rouhani]]. ==Presidential campaigns== [[File:Iran's 2013 presidential election first debate 38.jpg|thumb|Velayati at election debate 2013]] ===2005 presidential election=== Velayati was under consideration by the conservative alliance of Iran as a possible candidate for [[Iranian presidential election, 2005|2005 presidential election]], but he announced that he did not accept candidacy of the conservative alliance and would run as an [[Independent politician|Independent]]. He finally decided not to run. It was speculated that he did not want to run against [[Ali Akbar Rafsanjani|Rafsanjani]]. ===2013 presidential election=== He announced his candidacy for the [[Iranian presidential election, 2013|2013 presidential election]] and was supported by some conservative groups. He promised a strong external relationship with community reconciliation, and more diplomatic relations with Europe and the United States. He also criticized [[President of Iran|President]] [[Ahmadinejad]]'s foreign policy.[http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/spotlight/iranelections/2013/05/2013521111920821747.html Candidates profile] Al Jazeera, 21 May 2013 He received 2,268,753 of the votes, coming in fifth place. ==Works== Velayati has had a large number of books and academic works published, including: * ''Dynamism of Islamic and Iranian Culture and Civilization'' * ''Iran and the Question of Palestine'' * ''Iran and the Developments of Palestine'' * ''Historical Crisis of Iranian Identity'' * ''Intellectual Prelude to Constitutional Movement'' * ''History of Iran Foreign Relations under Shah Abbas Safavid I'' * ''History of Iran Foreign Relations under Shah Ismail Safavid II'' * ''Political History of the Iraqi Imposed War Against the Islamic Republic of Iran'' * ''History of Iran Foreign Relations under Nasser addin Shah and Mozaffar addin Shah'' * ''Tuberculosis'' * ''Infectious Diseases'' ==References== '''Beverly Stranger''' was a Canadian Indigenous track and field athlete with blindness, from the Timiskaming Band of [[Notre-Dame-du-Nord, Quebec|Notre Dame du Nord, Quebec]].<ref name=":3" /> She competed at the [[1976 Summer Paralympics|1976 Toronto Olympics for the Physically Disabled]], and the 1977 Ontario Summer games held in [[Brantford|Brantford, Ontario]]. Stranger was a recipient of the prestigious [[Tom Longboat Awards|Tom Longboat Award]] in 1976, only the second female to have done so and the first disabled athlete.<ref name=":2">{{cite journal|last1=Forsyth|first1=Janice|title=The Power to Define: History of the Tom Longboat Awards|date=2005|pages=128–129|url=https://search-proquest-com.ledproxy2.uwindsor.ca/pqdtglobal/docview/305364428/previewPDF/61758C26D3CB48FEPQ/1?accountid=14789|accessdate=28 October 2017}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{cite book|last1=Forsyth|first1=Janice|last2=Giles|first2=Audrey R.|title=Aboriginal Peoples & Sport in Canada|date=2013|publisher=UBC Press|location=Vancouver|isbn=978-0-7748-2420-0|pages=82}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=file:///C:/Users/User/Downloads/hearld%20aug%2012%201976%20pg%2010.pdf|title="Canada's Best showing"|last=|first=|date=August 12, 1976|work=The Lethbridge Herald|access-date=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130812155911/http://c/|archive-date=2013-08-12|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://search-proquest-com.ledproxy2.uwindsor.ca/hnpglobeandmail/docview/1239402836/pageviewPDF/171C046DFD38434DPQ/1?accountid=14789|title="Canada Wins 4 more Gold at the Olympiad"|last=|first=|date=August 10, 1976|work=The Globe and Mail|access-date=October 28, 2017}}</ref>
== Early life == Stranger was of Abenaki Algonquin descent, originally from the Timiskiming Band of Notre Dame du Nord, Quebec.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://atfn.ca/Community.html|title=Timiskaming First Nation|website=atfn.ca|access-date=2017-10-28}}</ref> Later in her life, she resided in Schumacher, Ontario.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":0" /> She attended the [[W. Ross Macdonald School|W. Ross Macdonald school for the blind]] in 1977, where she competed in track and field events.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.brantfordexpositor.ca/2012/05/23/flashback-with-kim-hartley-june-14|title="Flashback with Kim Hartley June 14th"|last=Hartley|first=Kim|date=June 14, 2017|work=Brantford Expositor|access-date=October 28, 2017}}</ref>
== Athletic achievements == Stranger competed in the [[1976 Summer Paralympics|1976 Toronto Olympics for the Physically Disabled]]. She won a gold in the high jump, followed by two silver medals in the javelin throw and the pentathlon.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":4" /> The following year in 1977 she participated in the Ontario Summer games held in Brantford, Ontario. Competing in various track and field events, she won another gold and an additional four silver medals.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Forsyth|first1=Janice|date=2005|title=The Power to Define: History of the Tom Longboat Awards|url=https://search-proquest-com.ledproxy2.uwindsor.ca/pqdtglobal/docview/305364428/previewPDF/61758C26D3CB48FEPQ/1?accountid=14789|pages=128–129|accessdate=28 October 2017}}</ref>
== Awards == Stranger was awarded the national [[Tom Longboat Awards|Tom Longboat Award]] in 1976 alongside [[Reginald Underwood]]. She was the second female winner of national award.<ref name=":2" />

{{Use British English|date=August 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{redirect2|Burke's|Burkes||Burke}} {{Infobox company | name =Burke's Peerage Limited | logo = Burkes-062012 square.gif | type = Private limited company | industry =Publishing | fate = | predecessor =Burke's Peerage (1826) Limited {{small|(2013–2016)}} | successor = | founded = {{Start date and age|1826}} in [[London]], [[England]] | founder = [[John Burke (genealogist)|John Burke]] | hq_location_city = [[Bury St Edmunds]], [[Suffolk]] | hq_location_country = England | area_served = | key_people = | products = | owner = | num_employees = | num_employees_year = | parent = | website ={{URL|burkespeerage.com}} }} '''Burke's Peerage Limited''' is a British [[genealogy|genealogical]] [[publisher]] founded in 1826, when Irish genealogist [[John Burke (genealogist)|John Burke]] began releasing books devoted to the ancestry and [[heraldry]] of the [[peerage]], [[baronetage]], [[knight]]age and [[landed gentry]] of the [[United Kingdom]]. His first publication, a ''Genealogical and Heraldic Dictionary of the Peerage and Baronetage of the United Kingdom'', was updated sporadically until 1847, when the company began releasing new editions every year as ''Burke's Peerage, Baronetage and Knightage'' (often shortened to just ''Burke's Peerage''). Other books followed, including ''[[Burke's Landed Gentry]]'', ''Burke's Colonial Gentry'', and ''Burke's General Armory''. In addition to the peerage, Burke's published books on royal families of [[Europe]] and [[Latin America]], ruling families of [[Africa]] and the [[Middle East]], distinguished families of the [[United States]] and historical families of [[Ireland]]. ==History== The firm was established in 1826 by John Burke (1786–1848), progenitor of a dynasty of [[genealogist]]s and [[herald]]s. His son Sir [[Bernard Burke|John Bernard Burke]] (1814–92) was [[Ulster King of Arms]] (1853–92) and his grandson, Sir [[Henry Farnham Burke]] (1859–1930), was [[Garter Principal King of Arms]] (1919–30). After his death, ownership passed through a variety of people. [[Image:Burke's Peerage, Sixth Edition (1839), Title Page.jpg|thumb|195px|''A Genealogical and Heraldic Dictionary of the Peerage and Baronetage of the British Empire, Sixth Edition 1839'' (known better simply as ''Burke's Peerage'')|left]] Apart from the Burke family, editors have included [[Arthur Charles Fox-Davies]], [[Alfred Trego Butler]], [[Leslie Gilbert Pine]], and [[Hugh Montgomery-Massingberd]]. ==Criticism== From the start, Burke's works suffered from pomposity and carelessness. Readers may have accepted as a minor eccentricity of style the idolisation of medieval figures who were little more than brigands and the ludicrously reverential tone adopted towards otherwise insignificant people who happened to possess a title or were related to a titled person. The major fault of substance, however, was the frequent and evident inaccuracy of the articles. Without much knowledge of history or genealogy, one could see improbabilities and inconsistencies both within articles and between articles. Errors in existing articles remained uncorrected between editions and new errors were added in new articles. A very minor example can be found as late as 1953, where the article on the [[Baron Baden-Powell|Baden-Powell]] barony contained a statement about the relationship of the first baron (died 1941) to the family of the first [[Earl Nelson]] (died 1835) which was not supported by the article on the Nelson earldom, because there was no relationship and the statement was untrue.{{cite|title = Burke's Peerage|year = 1953|edition = 100|location = London|publisher = Burke's Peerage Ltd|editor = L. G. Pine|pages = 1544 and 1704}}[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.$c148190;view=1up;seq=1973] When such carelessness was shown over relatively recent links, what hope had readers of finding accurate guidance over titles with complicated ascents going back to remote medieval times? [[File:Burke's Peerage, Sixth Edition, 1839, Frontispiece.jpg|thumb|right|
Sir John Bernard Burke,
''Burke's Peerage'' frontispiece (62nd edition, 1900)
]] Serious scholars have always taken little account of Burke's books, exposing their flaws from time to time. In 1877, the Oxford professor [[Edward Augustus Freeman]] attacked ''in language of almost unexampled scorn, the fables and the fictions'' in Burke's,{{cite|title = Studies in Peerage and Family History|first = J. Horace |last = Round|location = London|year = 1901|ISBN = 0-8063-0426-X|url = https://archive.org/details/round1910|access-date = 25 March 2018}} where he could readily find a pedigree that was ''purely mythical – if indeed mythical is not too respectable a name for what must be in many cases the work of deliberate invention …. (and) all but invariably false. As a rule, it is not only false, but impossible … not merely fictions, but exactly that kind of fiction which is, in its beginning, deliberate and interested falsehood.''{{cite|article = Pedigrees and Pedigree-Makers |title = Contemporary Review|volume = XXX |pages = 11 to 41|date = June 1877|first = Edward A.|last = Freeman }} The reputation of the imprint in informed circles was well established by 1893 when [[Oscar Wilde]] in the play ''[[A Woman of No Importance]]'' wrote: "You should study the Peerage, Gerald. It is the one book a young man about town should know thoroughly, and it is the best thing in fiction the English have ever done!" Such barbs had little effect for, writing in 1901, the historian [[J. Horace Round]] aimed many blows at the ''old fables'' and ''grotesquely impossible tales'' still being perpetuated by Burke's. == See also == * ''[[Almanach de Gotha]]'' * ''[[Burke’s Landed Gentry]]'' * ''[[Debrett's|Debrett's Peerage & Baronetage]]'' * [[Royal family|European royalty]] * [[Hereditary peer]]s * [[Life Peer]]s * [[Baronet]]s [[File:Coat of Arms of the Norroy and Ulster King of Arms.svg|thumb|right|125px| Arms of office of '''Sir Bernard Burke''']] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.burkespeerage.com/ Burke's Peerage website] * [http://www.burkespeeragefoundation.org/ Burke's Peerage Foundation website] * [http://www.college-of-arms.gov.uk/ College of Arms website] * [http://www.lyon-court.com/ Lyon Court website] * [http://www.baronetage.org/ Standing Council of the Baronetage website] ==Online Editions== * [https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=nyp.33433081841102;view=1up;seq=14 1st edition - '''Colonel Frederick''' is a pseudonym of the 18th-century author of ''Memoirs of [[Corsica]], Containing the Natural and Political History of that Important Island,'' 1768, and of ''The Description of Corsica,'' 1795. He was born c.1725 and came to London c.1750, but his place of origin is unknown. He claimed to be the son of King [[Theodore of Corsica]], and adopted the title of Prince of [[Caprera]], serving in the army of King [[Frederick II of Prussia]] then acting as agent in London for the [[Duke of Württemberg]]. He was probably an impostor, and according to some intelligence reports may have been a [[Poland|Polish]] Jew called Wigliawiski. Though penniless, he managed to gain the acquaintance of those in high circles and was for a time accepted into society. He died in poverty in 1797.<ref name="Lettre à Pascal Paoli">{{cite book | title=''Lettre à Pascal Paoli'', trans. Éditions Materia Scritta, Bastia, 2005. | author=François de Negroni | year=2005}}</ref>
Frederick wrote an account of his purported father's life, ''Memoires pour servir a l'histoire de la Corse'', and also an English translation, both published in London in 1768. In 1795 he published an enlarged edition, ''A Description of Corsica'', with an account of its union to the crown of Great Britain. See also Fitzgerald, King Theodore of Corsica (London, 1890).

{{short description|Western Roman Emperor from 407 to 411}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{good article}} {{EngvarB|date=May 2018}} {{distinguish|Constantius III|Constantine III (Byzantine emperor)}} {{Infobox monarch | name =Constantine III | full name =Flavius Claudius Constantinus | succession =[[Roman Emperor|Emperor of the Roman Empire]] | image = Constantineiii.jpg | caption =Coin of Constantine III. | reign =Usurper 407–409 (against Emperor [[Honorius (emperor)|Honorius]])
Co-emperor 409–411 (with Honorius and [[Constans II (usurper)|Constans II]]) | predecessor =[[Gratian (usurper)|Gratian]] | successor =[[Honorius (emperor)|Honorius]] | spouse 1 = name unknown | spouse 2 = | issue =[[Constans II (usurper)|Constans II]]
Julianus,Jones, pg. 638
[[Ambrosius Aurelianus]] (legend) | dynasty = | father = | mother = | religion = [[Nicene Christianity]] | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date =411 (before 18 September) | death_place = | place of burial = ||title=[[Augustus (honorific)|Augustus]] of the [[Western Roman Empire]]|regnal name=Imperator Caesar Flavius Claudius Constantius Augustus|moretext=(With [[Honorius (emperor)|Honorius]])}} '''Flavius Claudius Constantinus''',Jones, pg. 316 known in English as '''Constantine III''' (died shortly before 18 September 411) was a [[Roman Empire|Roman]] general who declared himself [[Western Roman Emperor]] in [[Roman Britain|Britannia]] in 407 and established himself in [[Gaul]]. He was co-emperor from 409 until 411. Constantine rose to power during a bloody struggle in Roman Britain and was acclaimed emperor by the local legions in 407. He promptly moved to [[Gaul]], taking all of the mobile troops from Britain, to confront the various Germanic invaders who had crossed the Rhine the previous winter. Constantine gained the upper hand after several battles with the forces of the [[Western Roman Emperor]] [[Honorius (emperor)|Honorius]]. As a result, Honorius recognised Constantine as co-emperor in 409. The activities of the invading tribes, raids by Saxons on the near-defenseless Britain and desertions by some of his top commanders led to a collapse of support. After further military setbacks he abdicated in 411. He was captured and executed shortly afterwards. ==Life== [[File:Roman Gaul - AD 400.png|thumb|Roman Gaul prior to the crossing of the Rhine]] In 406, the provinces of [[Roman Britain]] revolted. The garrisons had not been paid and had determined to choose their own leader.Zosimus, 6:1:2 Their first two choices, [[Marcus (usurper)|Marcus]] and [[Gratian (usurper)|Gratian]], did not meet their expectations and were killed. Fearful of a Germanic invasion and desperate for some sense of security in a world that seemed to be rapidly falling apart, the Roman military in Britain sought greater security in strong and able military leadership and chose as their leader a man named after the famed emperor of the early fourth century, [[Constantine the Great]], who had himself risen to power through a military coup in Britain.Zosimus, 7:40:5 Constantine was a common soldier, but one of some ability.Orosius, 7:40:4 Early in 407, they acclaimed him as emperor.{{Harvcolnb|Snyder|1998|pp=19}}, ''Age of Tyrants''. Constantine moved quickly. He crossed the [[English Channel|Channel]] at [[Boulogne-sur-Mer|Bononia]] (Boulogne) and (historians have assumed) took with him all of the mobile troops left in Britain, thus denuding the province of any first line military protection and explaining the disappearance of the legions from Britannia in the early fifth century.Elton, ''Constantine III (407–411 A.D.)'' The Roman forces in Gaul (modern France) declared for him, followed by most of those in Hispania (modern Spain). On 31 December 406 several tribes of [[barbarian]] invaders, including the [[Vandal]]s, the [[Burgundians]], the [[Alans]] and the [[Suebi|Sueves]] had [[Crossing of the Rhine|crossed the Rhine]], perhaps near [[Mainz]], and overrun the Roman defensive works in a successful invasion of the [[Roman Empire|Western Roman Empire]].Bury, pg. 138 Constantine's forces won several confrontations with the Vandals and quickly secured the line of the Rhine. The sitting Western emperor, [[Flavius Augustus Honorius|Honorius]], ordered [[Stilicho]], his leading general, or ''[[magister militum]]'', to expel Constantine. [[Sarus (Goth)|Sarus the Goth]], a commander of Honorius, defeated two of Constantine's generals, [[Iustinianus]] and the [[Franks|Frank]] [[Nebiogastes]], who were leading the vanguard of his forces.Birley, pg. 460 Constantine's lieutenant, Nebiogastes, was first trapped in, then killed outside, [[Valence, Drôme|Valence]].Zosimus, 6:2:3 Constantine sent another army headed by [[Edobichus]] and [[Gerontius (general)|Gerontius]], and Sarus retreated into [[Italy]], needing to buy his passage through the [[Alps|Alpine]] passes from the brigand [[Bagaudae]], who controlled them.Zosimus, 6:2:4 With these advances, Constantine controlled all of Gaul and garrisoned the Alpine passes into Italy.Birley, pgs. 458–459 By May 408 he had made [[Arles]] his capital,Bury, pg. 140 where he appointed [[Apollinaris (praefect)|Apollinaris]], the grandfather of [[Sidonius Apollinaris]], as prefect.Jones, pg. 113 ===Recognition as co-emperor=== In the summer of 408, the Roman forces in Italy assembled to counterattack. [[Hispania]] was a stronghold of the [[House of Theodosius]] and loyal to the ineffectual Honorius. Constantine feared that Honorius' cousins would organise an attack from that direction while troops under Sarus and Stilicho attacked him from Italy in a [[Pincer movement|pincer manoeuvre]]. He struck first at Hispania.Zosimus, 6:2:5 He summoned his eldest son, [[Constans II (usurper)|Constans]], from the [[monastery]] where he was dwelling, elevated him to [[Caesar (title)|Caesar]],Birley, pg. 459 and sent him with the general Gerontius towards Hispania, where they defeated the cousins of Honorius with little difficulty; two{{snd}}[[Didymus (cousin of Honorius)|Didymus]] and [[Verinianus]]{{snd}}were captured, and two others — [[Lagodius]] and [[Theodosiolus]] — escaped, Lagodius to [[Rome]] and Theodosiolus to [[Constantinople]].Gibbon, Ch. 30 Constans left his wife and household at [[Zaragoza, Spain|Saragossa]] under the care of Gerontius and returned to Arles to report to his father.Bury, pg. 141 Meanwhile, the loyalist Roman army mutinied at [[Ticinum]] ([[Pavia]]) on 13 August, which was followed by the execution of Honorius' general Stilicho on 22 August.Gibbon, Ch. 30 Intrigue within the Imperial court caused the general Sarus and his men to abandon the western army. This left Honorius in [[Ravenna]] without any significant military power, and facing a [[Goths|Gothic]] army under [[Alaric I|Alaric]] that roamed unchecked in northern Italy. So, when Constantine's envoys arrived to parley, the fearful Honorius recognised Constantine as co-emperor, and the two were joint [[Roman consul|consuls]] for the year 409. ===March on Italy=== That year was Constantine's high-water mark. While he had been fighting Honorius' armies, some of the Vandal tribes had overrun Constantine's Rhine defenses and spent two years and eight months burning and plundering their way through Gaul. The tribes reached the [[Pyrenees]], where they broke through Constantine's garrisons and entered Hispania. Constantine prepared to send his son Constans back to deal with this crisis when word came that his general Gerontius had rebelled, raising his relative, [[Maximus of Hispania]], as co-emperor. Despite Constantine's best efforts, the feared attack from Hispania come the following year, when Gerontius advanced with the support of his barbarian allies.Bury, pg.142 At about the same time [[Saxon people|Saxon]] [[pirate]]s raided Britain, which Constantine had left defenceless.Bury, pg. 143 Distressed that Constantine had failed to defend them, the Roman inhabitants of Britain and [[Armorica]] (Brittany) rebelled and expelled his officials.{{sfn|Higham|1992|pp=71–72}} Constantine's response to this tightening circle of enemies was a final desperate gamble. Encouraged by the entreaties of officials of the western court, he marched on Italy with the troops left to him.{{cn|date=August 2018}} They wanted to replace Honorius with a more capable ruler. Constantine, though, had insufficient forces and retreated into Gaul in the late spring of 410. Constantine's position became untenable; Gerontius defeated his forces at [[Vienne, Isère|Vienne]] in 411; there his son Constans was captured and executed. Constantine's praetorian prefect [[Decimus Rusticus]], who had replaced Apollinaris a year earlier, abandoned Constantine to be caught up in the new rebellion of [[Jovinus]] in the [[Rhineland]]. Gerontius trapped Constantine inside Arles and besieged him. ===Surrender and execution=== [[Image:Siliqua Constantine III-RIC 1355.jpg|thumb|250px|Constantine III portrayed on a [[siliqua]]. The reverse celebrates the victories of the ''[[Augustus (honorific)#In the divided Roman Empire|Augusti]]''.]] At the same time, Honorius found a new general, the future [[Constantius III]]. He arrived at Arles and put Gerontius to flight. Gerontius committed suicide and many of his troops deserted to Constantius, who took over the siege.{{cn|date=August 2018}} Constantine held out, hoping for the return of Edobichus, who was raising troops in northern Gaul amongst the [[Franks]]. But on his arrival Edobichus was defeated in an ambush.Bury, pg. 144 Constantine, his hopes fading after his troops guarding the Rhine abandoned him to support Jovinus, surrendered to Constantius. Despite the promise of safe passage, and Constantine's assumption of clerical office, Constantius imprisoned the former soldier and had him beheaded on his way to [[Ravenna]]{{cn|date=August 2018}} in either August or September 411.Jones, pg. 316 His head, on a pole, was presented to Emperor Honorius on 18 September. It was later displayed outside [[Carthage]]. Heather, pg. 237 [[Athaulf]] the [[Visigoth]] later suppressed the revolt of Jovinus.{{cn|date=August 2018}} Roman rule never returned to Britain after the death of Constantine III. As the historian [[Procopius]] later explained, "from that time onwards it remained under [the rule] of tyrants."Birley, pg. 160 ==Legend== Constantine III is also known as Constantine II of Britain. He is remembered as a [[List of legendary kings of Britain|King of the Britons]] in the [[Wales|Welsh]] chronicles and [[Geoffrey of Monmouth]]'s highly popular and imaginative ''[[Historia Regum Britanniae]]'', where he comes to power following [[Gracianus Municeps]]' reign. In this version, the Britons ask Aldroneus, the ruler of Armorica, to be their ruler too, seeking a king who can defend them against the barbarians. Aldroenus refuses, believing the country to have diminished, but sends his brother Constantine to rule instead. Constantine becomes King and has three sons, [[Constans II (son of Constantine III)|Constans]], [[Ambrosius Aurelianus|Aurelius]] and [[Uther Pendragon|Uther]], but is stabbed to death by a Pict.Monmouth, 6:5 Geoffrey seems to have conflated the historical Constantine III with an unrelated [[Cornwall|Cornish]] king of a similar name, [[Custennin Gorneu]].David Nash Ford's ''Early British Kingdoms'': [http://www.earlybritishkingdoms.com/bios/constcdm.html Constantine Corneu] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140301102049/http://www.earlybritishkingdoms.com/bios/constcdm.html |date=1 March 2014 }} This has led to confusion among modern scholars but, beyond their names, Geoffrey's fictional Constantine does not resemble the historical one.Peter Bartrum, ''A Welsh Classical Dictionary,'' National Library of Wales, 1993, pp. 157–158. ==See also== * [[End of Roman rule in Britain]] == References == {{Reflist|2}} ==Sources== ===Primary sources=== * [[Zosimus]], ''Historia Nova'', Books 5 & 6 [http://www.tertullian.org/fathers/zosimus06_book6.htm Historia Nova] * [[Paulus Orosius|Orosius]], ''Historiae adversum Paganos'', 7.40 * [[Geoffrey of Monmouth]]' ''[[Historia Regum Britanniae]]'' ===Secondary sources=== * Bartrum, Peter ''A Welsh Classical Dictionary'' Cardiff: National Library of Wales, 1993, {{ISBN|9780907158738}} * {{citation | last = Birley | first = Anthony | title =The Roman Government in Britain| publisher = Oxford University Press|location=Oxford | year = 2005 | isbn = 978-0-19-925237-4|ref=none}} * Bury, J. B., ''A History of the Later Roman Empire from Arcadius to Irene'', Vol. I (1889) London; New York: Macmillan OCLC 22138662 * [http://www.roman-emperors.org/westemp5.htm#Note Elton, Hugh, ''Constantine III (407–411 A.D.)'', ''D.I.R.''] * Ford, David Nash ''Early British Kingdoms'': [http://www.earlybritishkingdoms.com/bios/constcdm.html Constantine Corneu] * Gibbon, Edward, ''Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire'' (1888) Philadelphia : J.B. {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox Governor |name = Edward Telfair |image = |order1 = |office1 = [[List of Governors of Georgia|Governor of Georgia]] |term_start1 = January 9, 1786 |term_end1 = January 9, 1787 |predecessor1 = [[Samuel Elbert]] |successor1 = [[George Mathews (Georgia)|George Mathews]] |term_start2 = November 11, 1789 |term_end2 = November 7, 1793 |predecessor2 = [[George Walton]] |successor2 = [[George Mathews (Georgia)|George Mathews]] |birth_date = {{birth year|1735}}<!-- True birth date has been lost to history - "January 1" date from National Governors Association is only used as a placeholder birthday --> |birth_place = [[Scotland]] |death_date = {{death date and given age|1807|9|17|71–72}} |death_place = [[Savannah, Georgia]], U.S. |party = |spouse = |profession = |religion = |signature = }} '''Edward Telfair''' (1735<!-- True birth date has been lost to history - "January 1" date from National Governors Association is only used as a placeholder birthday --> – September 17, 1807) was the [[List of governors of Georgia|Governor]] of the state of [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] between 1786 and 1787, and again from 1790 through 1793. He was a member of the [[Continental Congress]], and a signer of the [[Articles of Confederation]].<ref>{{ cite web | url=http://www.nga.org/cms/home/governors/past-governors-bios/page_georgia/col2-content/main-content-list/title_telfair_edward.html | title=Georgia Governor Edward Telfair | publisher=[[National Governors Association]] | accessdate=October 10, 2013}}</ref>
==Early life== Telfair was born in 1735 on his family's ancestral estate in western [[Scotland]].<ref>Johnson, Charles J. "Edward Telfair (1735-1807)." ''[[New Georgia Encyclopedia]]''. May 26, 2015. Web. August 30, 2015.</ref> He graduated from the [[Kirkcudbright]] Grammar School, before acquiring commercial training. He immigrated to [[Thirteen Colonies|America]] in 1758 as an agent of a [[Commission (remuneration)|commission house]], settling in [[Province of Virginia|Virginia]]. Telfair subsequently moved to [[Halifax, North Carolina]], and finally to [[Savannah, Georgia]], where he established his own commission house.<ref>{{ cite web | url=http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=T000114 | title=TELFAIR, Edward, (1735–1807) | publisher=''[[Biographical Directory of the United States Congress]]'' | accessdate=October 10, 2013}}</ref> He arrived in Georgia in 1766, joining his brother, William, who had emigrated earlier.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Jackson|first1=Harvey H.|title=Edward Telfair|publisher=American National Biography|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=ers&AN=88829488&site=eds-live&scope=site|accessdate=May 31, 2016}}</ref> Together with Basil Cowper, Telfair built the commission house, and it was an overnight success.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Pressly|first1=Paul M.|title=Scottish Merchants and the Shaping of Colonial Georgia|journal=Georgia Historical Quarterly|date=2007|volume=91|issue=2|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=25565259&site=eds-live&scope=site|accessdate=May 31, 2016}}</ref>
===Slave owner=== Telfair was a [[slave owner]] and a consultant on slavery issues.<ref>Edward Telfair Papers, 1764–1831; 906 Items & 5 Volumes; Savannah, Georgia; "Papers of a merchant, governor of Georgia, and delegate to the Continental Congress".</ref> His mercantile firm dealt in slaves, among other things, and contemporary correspondence of his included discussions of such topics as: the management of slaves; the purchase and sale of slaves; runaway slaves; the mortality rate of slaves born on plantations; the difficulty of selling closely related slaves; and the relations between whites and [[Freedman|freedmen]].{{Citation needed|date=January 2012}}
==Revolutionary period== Telfair was a member of a [[Committee of Safety (American Revolution)|Committee of Safety]] (1775–1776), and was a delegate to the Georgia [[Provincial Congress]] meeting at Savannah in 1776. He was also a member of the Georgia [[Committee of Intelligence]] in 1776.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Jackson|first1=Harvey H.|title=Edward Telfair|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=ers&AN=88829488&site=eds-live&scope=site|publisher=American National Biography|accessdate=May 31, 2016}}</ref>
Telfair was elected to the Continental Congress for 1778, 1780, 1781, and 1782. He was a signatory to the [[Articles of Confederation]]. In 1783, during the [[Cherokee–American wars]], Telfair was commissioned to [[treaty|treat]] with the [[Chickamauga Cherokee]] Indians. Telfair was the designated agent (on behalf of Georgia) in talks aimed at settling the northern boundary dispute with [[North Carolina]] in February 1783. The land in question was generally regarded as Creek land, so the Cherokees readily signed the treaty. The Creeks refused.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Cashin|first1=Edward J.|title=The King's Ranger : Thomas Brown and the American Revolution on the Southern Frontier|date=1999|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York|isbn=9780820310930|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=nlebk&AN=16266&site=eds-live&scope=site&ebv=EB&ppid=pp_161|accessdate=May 31, 2016}}</ref> Although the citizens of Franklin County begged him to retaliate,<ref>{{cite web|title=1793 Jan. 1, Franklin County, [Georgia to] Edward Telfare [i.e., Telfair], Governor of Georgia / [citizens of] Franklin County|url=http://dbs.galib.uga.edu/cgi-bin/write_stats.cgi?stattype=fulltext&dbscode=zlna&format=jpg&redirect=http://purl.galileo.usg.edu/nativeamericandocs/jpg/tcc352a.jpg|website=Southeastern Native American Documents, 1730-1842|publisher=Digital Library of Georgia|accessdate=13 February 2018}}</ref> Secretary of War, [[Henry Knox]], instructed Governor Telfair not to retaliate against the Creek Indians.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Knox|first1=Henry|title=Henry Knox, Secretary of War, to Edward Telfair, Governor of Georgia|url=http://cdm16797.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/ref/collection/ONWT/id/571|website=Northwest Territory Collection, 1721-1825|publisher=Indiana Historical Society|accessdate=May 31, 2016}}</ref>
He served three terms as [[List of Governors of Georgia|Governor]] of the [[Georgia (U.S. state)|state of Georgia]]. During his second term as governor, he illegally granted thousands of acres of land to speculators as part of the [[Yazoo land fraud]].
==Later life== Telfair was one of only 12 men who received [[electoral votes]] during the first election for President and Vice President of the United States,<ref>[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=llsj&fileName=001/llsj001.db&recNum=5&itemLink=r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(sj00112)):%230010006&linkText=1 Journal of the Senate]; Vol. 1; 1789; p8.</ref> receiving the vote of one unrecorded elector from his home state of Georgia.
Telfair died in Savannah in 1807, interred initially in the family vault at ''Sharon'' plantation. Later in the 19th century, his remains were moved to [[Bonaventure Cemetery]] in Savannah.<ref>Johnson, Charles J. "Edward Telfair (1735-1807)." ''New Georgia Encyclopedia''. May 26, 2015. Web. August 30, 2015.</ref>
==Relations== One of Telfair's sons, [[Thomas Telfair]], represented Georgia in the [[Congress of the United States|U.S. Congress]].<ref>Johnson, Charles J. "Telfair Family." ''New Georgia Encyclopedia''. May 26, 2015. Web. August 30, 2015.</ref>
[[File:Telfair Academy.jpg|thumb|Telfair Academy, 1818, family mansion of Mary Telfair]]
The eldest of the Telfair daughters, [[Mary Telfair]], outlived her siblings and became the benefactor of the first public art museum in the [[Southern United States|American South]], now a complex of three buildings called the [[Telfair Museums]]. After her death in 1875, her will also provided for the founding of the Telfair Hospital for Females. Today it is known as Mary Telfair Women's Hospital and is part of Savannah's [[St. Joseph's/Candler]] health system.<ref>Johnson, Charles J. "Mary Telfair (1791-1875)." ''New Georgia Encyclopedia''. May 26, 2015. Web. August 30, 2015.</ref><ref>[http://www.sjchs.org/about-us/st-josephs-candler-history History of St. Joseph's/Candler] at hospital website.</ref>
==Legacy== Three months after Edward Telfair died, Georgia named [[Telfair County, Georgia|Telfair County]] after the former governor.
Later in the 19th century, Savannah's [[Squares of Savannah, Georgia|St. James Square was renamed Telfair Square]] to honor the family.
==See also== * [[List of U.S. state governors born outside the United States]]

Governor Edward Telfair] at [[National Governors Association]] site * {{FAG|6662528}}

[[Regal Entertainment]] (2014-present) | parents = Johnson Molina Dee
Maria Theresa Diño Velasquez | family = [[AJ Dee]] (brother) }} '''Ernest Lorenzo Velasquez Dee''' (born November 5, 1988) is a [[Filipino people|Filipino]] [[actor]], [[Model (person)|model]], and [[swimmer]]. Dee is a contract artist of [[ABS-CBN]]'s [[Star Magic]]. He came to prominence after starring in his first major TV drama ''[[Katorse]]'' (2009). He played the role of "Luis" in the Filipino remake ''[[Maria La Del Barrio (Philippine TV Series)|Maria la del Barrio]]'' (2011). He also starred in ''[[Ina, Kapatid, Anak]]'' (2012–13), and ''[[Muling Buksan Ang Puso]]'' He is the younger brother of actor and model, [[AJ Dee]]. ==Early life and education== Enchong Dee was born at 8:21 PM on Saturday, November 5, 1988 at Mother Seton Hospital in [[Naga, Camarines Sur]], to Johnson Molina Dee and Maria Theresa Diño Velasquez. He has two brothers, Angel James Dee, who is also an actor, while his younger brother, Isiah Dee, is a student in [[De La Salle–College of Saint Benilde]]. Enchong also has a young sister, Angelika Dee, who is a student in [[Immaculate Conception Cathedral School]] in [[Cubao]], Quezon City. He graduated from Naga Hope Christian School. He further pursued his swimming career at [[De La Salle University]] in Manila. Dee was part of the Philippine national swimming team and has participated in the [[SEA Games]] and [[2006 Asian Games]].{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} ==Career== Dee's first TV appearance in television came in 2006 when he appeared in a Philippine talk show ''[[Homeboy (Philippines TV show)|Homeboy]]'' as one of the guests. He caught the eye of a modeling agency and advertisers and soon appeared in several advertising campaigns including Close Up, [[Bench (Philippine clothing brand)|Bench]], [[KFC]] and [[Timex Group|Timex]]. In May 2007, Dee's contract with [[KFC]] expired and he transferred to [[Jollibee]] as a new endorser. Dee landed several acting roles beginning in 2007 which have included ''Abt Ur Luv'', ''Sineserye'', ''Komiks'', ''Your Song'' and ''[[My Girl (Philippine TV series)|My Girl]]''. In 2009, he was added to the main cast of ''[[Katorse]]'', an adaptation of the 1968 film (that was also remade in 1981). In 2010, he then reunited with some of his co-stars, [[Erich Gonzales]] and [[Ejay Falcon]], in ''[[Tanging Yaman]]''. He then became part of ''[[Magkaribal]]''. He starred in the film, ''[[Sa 'yo Lamang]]'' where he gained award nominations and won the Gawad PASADO for Best Supporting Actor. Enchong gained his first movie lead role, alongside his premiere leading lady, [[Erich Gonzales]], in ''[[I Do (2010 film)|I Do]]. In 2011, he starred in the Philippines' remake of ''[[Maria La Del Barrio (Philippine TV Series)|Maria La Del Barrio]]'' as Luis de la Vega. He recently appeared in the 2012 film, ''The Reunion'', with [[Enrique Gil]], [[Xian Lim]] and [[Kean Cipriano]]. After co-starring in 2012-2013 teleserye ''[[Ina, Kapatid, Anak]]'' alongside [[Kim Chiu]] and [[Maja Salvador]], he appeared in [[Muling Buksan Ang Puso]] with [[Julia Montes]] and [[Enrique Gil]]. Enchong won the one-million pesos briefcase in the August 18, 2012 episode of "Kapamilya Deal Or No Deal" together with his "The Reunion" co-star [[Kean Cipriano]]. In 2014, Dee release his first carrier single, ''Chinito Problems'', as response to [[Yeng Constantino]]'s 2013 hit ''Chinito''. ==Filmography== ===Television=== {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" ! '''Erkki Rapo''' (July 2, 1946 – February 28, 2004), also known as "Uncle Eki" and to international celebrities as "Eric", was a [[Finland|Finnish]] amateur [[autograph]] collector. He dedicated the last 40 years of his life to his hobby, and is among its best-known practitioners worldwide.
==Biography== Erkki Rapo lived a rather nomadic, lonely life. He had a series of odd jobs, including stints as limousine driver, club MC and porter at a local university campus. However, autograph hunting was his passion and he never held a job for long. He never married, and his apartment has been described by those who visited it as "chaotic". One of his few friends was [[Jukka Häkkinen]] who served as Rapo's personal driver from the late 1980s until his death. Rapo was diagnosed with [[diabetes]] as a child and suffered from the condition throughout his life.
Rapo's celebrity encounters began in 1959 when he met [[Paul Anka]] before a concert in [[Helsinki]]. Over the following years Rapo made it his mission to meet other famous people in person, and he would spend hours planning and executing his autograph-hunting campaigns. In 1966 Rapo met [[The Beatles]] and managed to obtain all four signatures, which is considered something of a rarity because only [[John Lennon]] and [[Paul McCartney]] are regarded by autograph experts as consistent autograph signers. Rapo also met and obtained autographs from [[Jim Morrison]], [[Frank Sinatra]], [[Plácido Domingo]], [[Boris Yeltsin]], [[Pope John Paul II]] and various other celebrities and notables. [[Tom Jones (singer)|Tom Jones]] considered Rapo a personal friend, even though his visits to Finland were limited by his tour schedules.
Along with the [[album cover]]s, [[magazine]]s and similar items favoured by autograph hunters, Rapo is said to have had supermarket receipts, plain paper and other odd items signed. He is said to have regularly carried autographed items with him, and many times he would try to sell these or offer them to a [[gas]] station or food store owner in return for gas or meals. Sometimes, if a buyer thought his prices were too high, he would photocopy the signed item and sell a fake autograph, albeit for less money than originally asked for.
As a result of his activities Rapo became a celebrity himself in Finland. He appeared several times in Finnish newspapers alongside the individual whose autograph he was seeking, and curious readers called the newspapers to ask about him. This motivated journalists to find out more about Rapo, and his life was later chronicled in Finland through newspaper interviews and articles.
In 1988 Rapo's collection was displayed at the [[Martinus Hall]] in [[Vantaa]].
==Bob Dylan incidents== Rapo tried to obtain [[Bob Dylan]]'s autograph on a number of occasions. Dylan apparently disliked this. There are accounts of a 1989 encounter between Dylan and Rapo in Helsinki, where Dylan allegedly shouted at Rapo to stop following him. Rapo nevertheless went the next day to Dylan's [[hotel]] but Dylan, signing autographs for a younger crowd, left the area upon spotting Rapo.
In 1996, Rapo and Dylan crossed paths again, at a music festival. According to Rapo, Dylan told him that he didn't like giving autographs to adults, and stepped away.
==Later years== Rapo did not stop autograph hunting until late in his life when, affected by diabetes complications, he scheduled fewer autograph-seeking dates. Rapo's illness forced him to stay at home for a large part of his final few years, until he died in 2004. His death was relayed by Finnish newspapers to readers across the nation.{{OR|date=June 2015}}
==Auction== Shortly after Rapo's death, his autograph collection was [[auction]]ed by well known dealer [[Martin Sinisalo]] in Helsinki. His biography "Hei anna nimmari - Eki-Sedän stoori" by [[Tomi Lindblom]] & Jukka Hakkinen was published in 2006.

''[[Alone Together (TV series)|Alone Together]]'' | website = }} '''Esther Lauren Povitsky''' (born March 2, 1988), also known as "'''Little Esther,'''" is an American actress, comedian, writer, and producer living in [[Los Angeles, California]]. She is the co-creator and star of the comedy series [[Alone Together (TV series)|''Alone Together'']]. ==Early life== Povitsky was born in [[Skokie, Illinois]]. She is of [[Jewish]] descent.{{cite web|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/for-a-couple-of-jewish-millennial-bffs-poor-and-platonic-equals-funny/|title=For a couple of Jewish millennial BFFs, poor and platonic equals funny|publisher=|accessdate=6 October 2018}} ==Career== In 2006 Povitsky graduated from [[Niles North High School]] in Skokie, IL. She moved to Los Angeles to pursue stand-up comedy and acting full-time after attending the [[University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign]]. She studied comedy at [[iO Chicago]], [[The Second City]], and [[The Groundlings]].{{cite web |title=Esther Povitsky - LA Casting |url=https://www.lacasting.com/Esther |accessdate=2 November 2018}} She frequently performs [[stand-up comedy]] at venues throughout [[Los Angeles|Los Angeles, California]], including [[The Comedy Store]], [[The Ice House (comedy club)|The Ice House]],{{cite web|url=http://icehousecomedy.com/comedian.cfm?id=5331 |title=The Ice House :: Esther Povitsky |publisher=Icehousecomedy.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-09}} and [[The Improv]].{{cite web|url=http://www.improv.com/Comedian/Little-Esther|title=Little Esther - Comedian - Improv.com|date=12 September 2011|website=Improv.com|accessdate=29 January 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110912125437/http://www.improv.com/Comedian/Little-Esther|archivedate=12 September 2011}} She currently plays Maya on the critically acclaimed series ''[[Crazy Ex-Girlfriend (TV series)|Crazy Ex Girlfriend]]''. Other recent television appearances include ''[[Brooklyn Nine-Nine]]'', [[Love (TV series)|''Love'']], and ''[[Parks and Recreation]].'' Povitsky also survived several rounds of 2015's ''[[Last Comic Standing]]'' (season 9).{{Cite news|url=http://www.buddytv.com/articles/last-comic-standing/last-comic-standing-season-9-p-57089.aspx|title='Last Comic Standing' Season 9 Premiere Recap: Meeting The Comedians|website=Buddytv.com|access-date=2016-12-05}} Povitsky was the first female guest to appear on ''[[The Joe Rogan Experience]]'', after which she began podcasting with DEATHSQUAD regularly. She hosted ''Little Esther's Piecast''{{cite web|url=http://deathsquad.tv/?s=piecast&x=0&y=0|title=Search Results piecast |website=Deathsquad.tv|accessdate=24 February 2016}} and currently co-hosts ''Brode & Esther'' with fellow comedian [[Brody Stevens]]{{cite web|url=http://deathsquad.tv/?s=esther+brode&x=0&y=0|title=Search Results esther brode |website=Deathsquad.tv|accessdate=24 February 2016}} as well as ''Weird Adults with Little Esther''{{cite web|url=http://feralaudio.com/category/weird-adults-little-esther/ |title=Feral Audio // Weird Adults with Little Esther |publisher=Feralaudio.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-09}} and ''Glowing Up with Esther and Caroline''.{{cite web|url=http://www.feralaudio.com/show/glowing-up/ |title=Feral Audio //Glowing Up with Esther and Caroline |publisher=Feralaudio.com |date=|accessdate=2017-10-13}} She often appears as a guest on the network's ''Ice House Chronicles''.{{cite web|url=http://deathsquad.tv/?s=little+esther+ice+house&x=0&y=0|title=Search Results little esther ice house |website=Deathsquad.tv|accessdate=24 February 2016}} In 2012, Povitsky turned down an offer from MTV to do a reality show based on her life as a comedian because she felt the series would be too invasive.[https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/tv/belgian-man-arrested-in-los-angeles-for-allegedly-stalking-comedian-esther-povitsky/2012/02/29/gIQAIuyShR_story.html Belgian Man Arrested in Los Angeles for Allegedly Stalking Comedian Esther Povitsky - Washington Post]{{dead link|date=April 2014}}{{cite web|author=Associated Press  |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/02/29/pierre-van-lint-arrested_n_1310240.html |title=Pierre Van Lint, Belgian Man, Arrested For Allegedly Stalking Comedian Esther Povitsky |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date=2012-02-29 |accessdate=2014-04-09}}[http://www.newsday.com/news/belgian-man-arrested-in-la-for-alleged-stalking-1.3565870 Belgian Man Arrested in LA for Alleged Stalking - Newsday]{{dead link|date=April 2014}} ===''Alone Together''=== {{main|Alone Together (TV series)}} In 2015, Povitsky wrote, starred in, and self-produced the short film ''Alone Together''. The short was later adapted into a pilot for [[Freeform (TV channel)|Freeform]], produced by [[The Lonely Island]].{{Cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2016/07/freeform-order-alone-together-comedy-pilot-esther-povitsky-lonely-island-1201782794/|title=Freeform Greenlights ‘Alone Together’ Comedy Pilot From Lonely Island|last=Petski|first=Denise|date=2016-07-05|newspaper=Deadline|language=en-US|access-date=2016-12-05}} In December 2016, the pilot was picked up to series.{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2016/tv/news/alone-together-freeform-series-the-lonely-island-1201943593/|title=Freeform Greenlights The Lonely Island’s Comedy ‘Alone Together’|last=Wagmeister|first=Elizabeth|date=2016-12-15|newspaper=Variety|language=en-US|access-date=2016-12-17}} In October, 2017, Freeform renewed the series for a second season ahead of its January 2018 debut.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/10/alone-together-renewed-season-2-freeform-lonely-island-esther-povitsky-benji-aflalo-1202190512/|title=The Lonely Island’s ‘Alone Together’ Gets Season 2 Renewal Ahead Of January Premiere On Freeform|last=Pedersen|first=Erik|publisher=Deadline|date=October 18, 2017|accessdate=October 21, 2017}} ==Filmography== {| class="wikitable sortable" ! {{notability|date=January 2018}} [[File:Nov-Dec_FP_Global_Thinkers_cover.jpeg|thumb|right|Nov./Dec. 2015 Global Thinkers issue]] ''[[Foreign Policy]]'' magazine recognizes the world's pre-eminent [[thought leader]]s and [[public intellectual]]s in an annual issue, "100 Leading Global Thinkers".{{cite web|title=Parcak named to 100 Global Thinkers list by Foreign Policy Magazine|url=http://www.uab.edu/news/faculty/item/7831-parcak-named-to-100-global-thinkers-list-by-foreign-policy-magazine|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170523040708/http://www.uab.edu/news/faculty/item/7831-parcak-named-to-100-global-thinkers-list-by-foreign-policy-magazine|archivedate=May 23, 2017|publisher=[[University of Alabama at Birmingham]]|accessdate=May 23, 2017|deadurl=yes|df=}} The list has become one of ''Foreign Policy''{{'}}s most-read features.{{cite web|title=Global Thinkers: Foreign Policy Group|url=https://fpgroup.foreignpolicy.com/global-thinkers-gala/|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170523040212/https://fpgroup.foreignpolicy.com/global-thinkers-gala/|archivedate=May 23, 2017|publisher=[[Foreign Policy]]|accessdate=May 23, 2017|deadurl=yes|df=}} Honorees include a range of [[leader]]s, advocates, innovators, artists, government officials, and visionaries from around the world. The editors of ''Foreign Policy'' select the 100 global thinkers based on their standout contributions over the previous year and their ability to translate ideas into action that change and shape the world. Since 2011, ''Foreign Policy'' has honored these leaders at an annual celebration, held at the time of the release of the print issue, in [[Washington, D.C.]] ==Lists== ===2005 list=== This was known in that year as the "2005 Prospect/FP Top 100 Public Intellectuals Poll". It was conducted with ''[[Prospect (magazine)|Prospect]]'' magazine.{{cite web|url=http://www.prospectmagazine.co.uk/prospect-100-intellectuals/ |title=Prospect/FP Top 100 Public Intellectuals Results |date=15 October 2005 |publisher=Prospect magazine |accessdate=12 December 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090930143349/http://www.prospectmagazine.co.uk/prospect-100-intellectuals/ |archivedate=30 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite web|title=The Prospect/FP Top 100 Public Intellectuals|url=https://www.infoplease.com/prospectfp-top-100-public-intellectuals|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170523042340/https://www.infoplease.com/prospectfp-top-100-public-intellectuals|archivedate=May 23, 2017|publisher=infoplease|accessdate=May 23, 2017|deadurl=yes|df=}} More than 20,000 people voted in the poll. ===2008 list=== The 2008 list was the second list of top public intellectual conducted with ''[[Prospect (magazine)|Prospect]]'' magazine.{{cite web|title=Top 100 Public Intellectuals|url=https://www.povertyactionlab.org/sites/default/files/119%20FP,%20Top%20100%20Intellectuals.pdf|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170518160953/https://www.povertyactionlab.org/sites/default/files/119%20FP,%20Top%20100%20Intellectuals.pdf|archivedate=May 18, 2017|publisher=[[Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab]]|accessdate=May 19, 2017|deadurl=yes|df=}} The complete list of the "Top 100 Public Intellectuals" was published in May 2008.{{cite {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} [[File:Friedrich Schmiedl 1984 Paraguay stamp crop.jpg|thumb|Friedrich Schmiedl on a 1984 Paraguay stamp]] '''Friedrich Schmiedl''' (11 May 1902 – 11 September 1994<ref name=forum/>) was an [[Austria]]n rocket designer; known particularly for his development of [[rocket mail]].
==Rocket mail== Schmiedl was born in [[Schwertberg]] in Upper Austria, and from 1924 studied civil engineering at the ''[[Graz University of Technology|Technische Hochschule]]'' in [[Graz]].<ref name=forum>[http://austria-forum.org/af/Wissenssammlungen/Biographien/Schmiedl,%20Friedrich Schmiedel, Friedrich] Austria-forum, accessed 24 May 2014.</ref><ref name=astronautica>[http://www.astronautix.com/astros/schmiedl.htm Schmiedl, Friedrich] Encyclopedia Astronautica, accessed 23 May 2014.</ref>
He began experiments with [[solid-fuel rocket]]s in 1918. From 1924 the experiments took place at [[Schöckl]], a mountain about 15 km north of Graz.<ref name=forum/><ref name=astronautica/>
[[File:Schoeckl 10.JPG|thumb|Schöckl, where Schmiedl's rockets were launched]] On 2 February 1931 he launched a rocket from Schöckl, which contained 102 letters. It was operated by remote control and landed by parachute at [[Sankt Radegund bei Graz|St Radegund]], a village about 3 km away. More successful launches were subsequently made, to St Radegund and to [[Kumberg]], a village about 6 km away. [[Philatelist]]s became interested in collecting letters which had been sent by rocket. Schmiedl envisaged that mail could be sent between towns by rocket; however the Austrian Post Office was not persuaded.<ref name=forum/><ref name=astronautica/><ref name=mail>[http://www.philatel2.com/jubilee/id269.htm Rocket Mail] King George V Silver Jubilee stamps, accessed 23 May 2014.</ref><ref name=darling>[http://www.daviddarling.info/encyclopedia/S/Schmiedl.html Schmiedl, Friedrich] The Worlds of David Darling, accessed 23 May 2014.</ref>
He also worked on rockets used to collect meteorological data, and rockets for [[aerial photography]].<ref name=forum/><ref name=astronautica/>
The rocket mail launches eventually had to be discontinued: they were mostly financed by special postage stamps, and in 1934 the Austrian Post Office forbade this financing; in 1935 the Austrian government forbade the possession of explosives, so private rocket development could no longer be carried out.<ref name=forum/><ref name=astronautica/>
==Second World War and after== When the Second World War began, there was military interest in his work; however Schmiedl, not wishing his research to be used for military purposes, destroyed the research documents. After the war he declined an offer to work on rocket development in the USA. Staying in Austria, he worked on boat propulsion.<ref name=forum/><ref name=astronautica/>
Friedrich Schmiedl died in Graz in 1994. His bequest to the City of Graz was used to establish the ''Friedrich Schmiedl Foundation'', to support new ideas to improve communications in the region of Graz.<ref name=forum/><ref name=wirtschaft>[http://www.wirtschaft.graz.at/cms/beitrag/10066484/5084389/ Ing. Friedrich Schmiedl Foundation] Graz Business Server, accessed 23 May 2014.</ref>
==References== {{Commons category|Friedrich Schmiedl}} {{reflist}}
