{{good article}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Joseph Franklin Rutherford | image = J.F. Rutherford.gif | image_size = | caption = Joseph Franklin Rutherford | birth_date = November 8, 1869 | birth_place = [[Versailles, Missouri|Versailles]], [[Missouri]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1942|1|8|1869|11|8}} | death_place = [[San Diego]], [[California]] | nationality = [[United States|American]] | occupation = [[Lawyer]] | signature = Signature_of_Joseph_Franklin_Rutherford.png | spouse = Mary Malcolm Fetzer | children = Malcolm Rutherford }} {{Jehovah's Witnesses}}
'''Joseph Franklin Rutherford''' (November 8, 1869 – January 8, 1942), also known as Judge Rutherford, was the second president of the incorporated [[Watch Tower Bible and Tract Society of Pennsylvania]]. He played a primary role in the organization and [[Development of Jehovah's Witnesses doctrine|doctrinal development]] of [[Jehovah's Witnesses]],<ref>Leo P. Chall, ''Sociological Abstracts'', vol 26 issues 1–3, "Sociology of Religion", 1978, p. 193 col 2: "Rutherford, through the Watch Tower Society, succeeded in changing all aspects of the sect from 1919 to 1932 and created Jehovah's Witnesses—a charismatic offshoot of the Bible student community."</ref><ref>"The Embryonic State of a Religious Sect's Development: The Jehovah's Witnesses" ''Sociological Yearbook of Religion in Britain'', ed. Michael Hill, 1972, issue 5 pp 11–12: "Joseph Franklin Rutherford succeeded to Russell's position as President of Zion's Watch Tower Tract Society, but only at the expense of antagonizing a large proportion of the Watch Towers subscribers. Nevertheless, he persisted in moulding the Society to suit his own programme of activist evangelism under systematic central control, and he succeeded in creating the administrative structure of the present-day sect of Jehovah's Witnesses."</ref><ref>''The Twentieth century'', vol 153, 1953 p. 14: "This latter phenomenon, perhaps the most widely spread politico-religious movement at the present time, is linked, as are so many, with a source in America, in this case Judge Rutherford, the New York founder of Jehovah's Witnesses."</ref> which emerged from the [[Bible Student movement]] established by [[Charles Taze Russell]].
Rutherford began a career in law, working as a court stenographer, trial lawyer and prosecutor. He became a special judge in the 14th Judicial District of Missouri at some time after 1895.<ref>An Encyclopedia of Religion, by Vergilius Ferm, 1945, p. 674; New York Times, January 7, 1917, Section I, p. 9.</ref> He developed an interest in the doctrines of Watch Tower Society president Charles Taze Russell, which led to his joining the [[Bible Student movement]], and he was baptized in 1906. He was appointed the legal counsel for the Watch Tower Society in 1907, as well as a traveling representative prior to his election as president in 1917. His early presidency was marked by a dispute with the Society's board of directors, in which four of its seven members accused him of autocratic behavior and sought to reduce his powers. The resulting leadership crisis divided the Bible Student community and contributed to the loss of one-seventh of adherents by 1919 and thousands more by 1931.<ref>P.S.L. Johnson, ''The Present Truth and Herald of Christ's Epiphany'', April 1927, p. 66: "Since the Fall of 1923 ... from 20,000 to 30,000 Truth people the world over have left the Society."</ref><ref name="Penton 1997 50">{{harvnb|Penton|1997|p=50}}</ref><ref name="Rogerson 1969 p=37">{{harvnb|Rogerson|1969|p=37}}</ref> Rutherford and seven other Watch Tower executives were imprisoned in 1918 after charges were laid over the publication of ''The Finished Mystery'', a book deemed seditious for its opposition to [[World War I]].<ref>"Postwar Enlargement of the Theocratic Organization", ''The Watchtower'', July 15, 1950, p. 217</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Beckford|1975|p=24}}</ref>
Rutherford introduced many organizational and doctrinal changes that helped shape the current beliefs and practices of Jehovah's Witnesses.<ref name="Penton 1997 p=75">{{harvnb|Penton|1997|p=75}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Rogerson|1969|p=64}}</ref> He imposed a centralized administrative structure on the worldwide Bible Student movement, which he later called a [[theocracy]], requiring all adherents to distribute literature via door to door preaching and to provide regular reports of their preaching activity.<ref>"Testing and Sifting in Modern Times", ''The Watchtower'', June 15, 1987, p. 17</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Rogerson|1969|p=53}}</ref> He also instituted training programs for public speaking as part of their weekly meetings for worship. He established 1914 as the date of Christ's invisible return, asserted that Christ died on a [[Dispute about Jesus' execution method|tree rather than a cross]],<ref>[http://www.strictlygenteel.co.uk/riches/riches1.html ''Riches'', by J.F. Rutherford, Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society, 1936, p. 27], "Jesus was crucified, not on a cross... Jesus was crucified by nailing his body to a tree. ...[http://bible.cc/deuteronomy/21-22.htm (Deuteronomy 21:22,23)] ... [http://bible.cc/galatians/3-13.htm (Galatians 3:13)] ... [http://bible.cc/acts/5-30.htm Acts 5:30.]"</ref><ref>"Flashes of Light—Great and Small", ''The Watchtower'', May 15, 1995, p. 20.</ref> formulated the current Witness concept of [[Armageddon]] as God's war on the wicked, and reinforced the belief that the start of Christ's millennial reign was imminent. He condemned the observance of traditional celebrations such as Christmas and birthdays, the saluting of national flags and the singing of national anthems. He introduced the name "Jehovah's witnesses" in 1931 and the term "[[Kingdom Hall]]" for houses of worship in 1935.<ref>{{Harvnb|Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society|1993|p=319}}</ref>
He wrote twenty-one books and was credited by the Society in 1942 with the distribution of almost 400 million books and booklets.<ref>''Consolation'', May 27, 1942, p. 6. It is not clear from this publication whether this included the distribution of Russell's earlier writings.</ref> Despite significant decreases during the 1920s, overall membership increased more than sixfold by the end of Rutherford's 25 years as president.<ref>"Part 1—United States of America", ''1975 Yearbook of Jehovah's Witnesses'', p. 94, "...earthwide report shows that the Memorial of Jesus Christ's death on April 5, '''1917''', was attended by '''21,274'''.</ref><ref>''Jehovah's Witnesses in the Divine Purpose'', pp. 312–313: Memorial attendance figures in Rutherford's final years were 98,076 (1941) and 140,450 (1942)</ref>
==Early life==
Rutherford was born on November 8, 1869 to James Calvin Rutherford and Leonora Strickland and raised in near-poverty in a [[Baptist beliefs|Baptist]] farm family. Some sources list his place of birth as [[Boonville, Missouri]], but according to his death certificate he was born in [[Versailles, Missouri]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Penton|1997|p=47}}.</ref><ref name="ReferenceA">Dept. of Public Health, San Diego California, Joseph Franklin Rutherford, Certificate of Death issued February 6, 1942</ref> Rutherford developed an interest in law from the age of 16.<ref>{{Harvnb|Rogerson|1969|p=34}}.</ref> Although his father discouraged this interest, he allowed Rutherford to go to college under the condition that he pay for a laborer to take his place on the family farm. Rutherford took out a loan<ref name="Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society 1975 81">{{Harvnb|Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society|1975|p=81}}</ref> and helped to pay for his law studies by working as a door-to-door encyclopedia salesman and court stenographer.<ref name="Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society 1993 67">{{Harvnb|Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society|1993|p=67}}</ref>
===Law career=== Rutherford spent two years as a judge's intern, became an official court reporter at age 20, and was admitted to the [[Missouri]] bar in May 1892 at age 22.<ref name="Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society 1993 67"/> He became a trial lawyer for a law firm<ref name="Watchtower 1955, p. 175">"Modern History of Jehovah's Witnesses", ''Watchtower'', March 15, 1955, p. 175.</ref> and later served for four years in Boonville as a public prosecutor. He campaigned briefly for [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] presidential candidate [[William Jennings Bryan]].<ref name="Jehovah's Witnesses 1978">[[Barbara Grizzuti Harrison]], ''Visions of Glory – A History and Memory of Jehovah's Witnesses'', Simon & Schuster, 1978, chapter 6.</ref> He was appointed as a Special Judge in the Eighth Judicial Circuit Court of Missouri,<ref name="Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society 1993 67"/><ref name=timesjudge>''The New York Times'', January 17, 1919, Section I, p. 9, [https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1917/01/07/102307691.pdf As Retrieved 2010-03-02]</ref><ref>"Religion: Jehovah's Witness", ''Time'', June 10, 1935, [http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,883470,00.html Online]</ref><ref>Biographies of Rutherford in the March 15, 1955 ''Watchtower'' and 1975 ''Yearbook'' of Jehovah's Witnesses state that his appointment as Special Judge was in the Fourteenth Judicial Circuit.</ref> sitting as a substitute judge at least once when a regular judge was unable to hold court.<ref name="Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society 1975 81"/> As a result of this appointment he became known by the [[sobriquet]] Judge Rutherford. He was admitted to the New York bar in 1909 and admitted to practice before the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] the same year.<ref>{{Harvnb|Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society|1975|p=83}}</ref>
==Watch Tower Society== [[Image:Jfrutherford1911.jpg|thumb|left|Joseph F. Rutherford (1911)]] In 1894 Rutherford purchased the first three volumes of Charles Taze Russell's ''[[Studies in the Scriptures|Millennial Dawn]]'' series of Bible study textbooks from two [[colportage|colporteurs]] who visited his office. Rutherford, who then viewed all religions as insincere, shallow and hypocritical, was struck by Russell's sincerity and his sentiments towards religion, which mirrored his own view.<ref>{{harvnb|Wills|2007|p=131}} Wills (p. 131) claims Rutherford had never doubted God's existence, but Wills does not cite a source for that claim.</ref><ref>''The Watchtower'' (October 1, 1997, p. 6) cites a 1913 newspaper interview wherein Rutherford describes becoming an atheist after a Baptist minister claimed Rutherford's wife Mary would go to Hell because she had not been baptized.</ref> Rutherford immediately wrote to the Watch Tower Society to express appreciation for the books.<ref>{{harvnb|Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society|1993|p=67}}</ref> He was baptized twelve years later and he and his wife began holding Bible classes in their home.<ref name="Jehovah's Witnesses 1978"/> In 1907, he became legal counsel for the Watch Tower Society at its Pittsburgh headquarters, and from around that time began to give public talks as a "pilgrim" representative of the Society.<ref name="Watchtower 1955, p. 175"/> As Russell's health deteriorated, Rutherford represented him on trips to Europe<ref>"British Branch report", ''Watch Tower'', January 15, 1915, p. 26, Reprints 5616.</ref> and in April 1915 he was deputized to speak at a major debate with Baptist preacher J. H. Troy over four nights in Los Angeles before an audience of 12,000,<ref>{{harvnb|Rogerson|1969|p=30}}</ref> debating various subjects, including the state of the dead, hellfire and Christ's Second Coming.<ref>''Yearbook'', Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society, 1991, p. 73.</ref> Rutherford wrote a pamphlet, ''A Great Battle in the Ecclesiastical Heavens'', in defense of Russell<ref>[http://www.mostholyfaith.com/bible/Reprints/Z1915MAY.asp#Z131:1 "Judge Rutherford's Spicy Defense", ''Watch Tower'', May 1, 1915, p. 130. R5685.]</ref> and served as chairman of the Bible Students' Los Angeles convention in September 1916.
===Board of directors=== By 1916 Rutherford had become one of the seven directors of the Watch Tower Society; when Russell died on October 31, 1916 he joined vice-President Alfred I. Ritchie and Secretary-Treasurer William E. Van Amburgh on a three-man executive committee that ran the Pennsylvania corporation until a new president was elected at the annual general meeting the following January.<ref>{{harvnb|Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society|1993|p=647}}</ref> He also joined a five-person editorial committee to run ''The Watch Tower'' from the December 15, 1916 issue. Russell's [[Will (law)|will]], drawn up in 1907, had named the five people he wished to run the magazine after his death;<ref>[http://www.mostholyfaith.com/bible/Reprints/Z1916DEC.asp#Z358:1 Russell's Last Will and Testament, ''The Watch Tower'', December 15, 1916.]</ref> Rutherford appeared only on a second list of five alternative members to fill any vacancies that arose.<ref>{{harvnb|Penton|1997|p=48}}</ref>
Bible Student [[Alexander Hugh Macmillan|Alexander H. Macmillan]], who served as an aide to the executive committee, later wrote that tensions at the Watch Tower Society headquarters mounted as the day for election of the Society's officers approached. He wrote: "A few ambitious ones at headquarters were holding caucuses here and there, doing a little electioneering to get their men in. However, Van Amburgh and I held a large number of votes. Many shareholders, knowing of our long association with Russell, sent their proxies to us to be cast for the one whom we thought best fitted for office."<ref>{{harvnb|Macmillan|1957|p=68}}</ref> Macmillan, who claimed he had declined an offer from an ailing Russell months earlier to accept the position of president after his death,<ref>{{harvnb|Macmillan|1957|p=70}}</ref> agreed with Van Amburgh that Rutherford was the best candidate. According to Macmillan, "Rutherford did not know what was going on. He certainly didn't do any electioneering or canvassing for votes, but I guess he was doing some worrying, knowing if he was elected he would have a big job on his hands ... There is no doubt in our minds that the Lord's will was done in this choice. It is certain that Rutherford himself had nothing to do with it."<ref>{{harvnb|Macmillan|1957|p=71}}</ref>
===Presidency dispute=== {{Main article|Watch Tower Society presidency dispute (1917)}} On January 6, 1917, Rutherford, aged 47, was elected president of the Watch Tower Society, unopposed, at the [[Pittsburgh]] convention. By-laws passed by both the Pittsburgh convention and the board of directors stated that the president would be the executive officer and general manager of the Society, giving him full charge of its affairs worldwide.<ref>{{harvnb|Pierson et al| 1917|pp=5,6}}</ref>
By June, four of the seven Watch Tower Society directors—Robert H. Hirsh, Alfred I. Ritchie, Isaac F. Hoskins and James D. Wright— had decided they had erred in endorsing Rutherford's expanded powers of management, claiming Rutherford had become autocratic.<ref>{{harvnb|Pierson et al| 1917|p=4}}</ref> In June, Hirsch attempted to rescind the new by-laws and reclaim the board's authority from the president.<ref>{{harvnb|Rutherford| August 1917|p=12}}</ref> Rutherford later claimed he had by then detected a conspiracy among the directors to seize control of the society.<ref>{{harvnb|Rutherford| August 1917|pp=22–23}}</ref> In July, Rutherford gained a legal opinion from a [[Philadelphia]] corporation lawyer that none of his opposers were legally directors of the society. The Watch Tower Society's official 1959 account of its history claimed the legal advice given to the ousted directors confirmed that given to Rutherford;<ref>''Jehovah's Witnesses in the Divine Purpose'' (1959) p. 71, col. 2</ref> however, the pamphlets produced by the expelled board members at the time indicated that their legal advice, acquired from several attorneys, disagreed with Rutherford's.<ref>''Light After Darkness'' (September 1, 1917) p. 11</ref><ref>''Facts for Shareholders'' (November 15, 1917) p. 14</ref> On July 12, Rutherford filled what he claimed were four vacancies on the board, appointing Macmillan and Pennsylvania Bible Students W. E. Spill, J. A. Bohnet and George H. Fisher as directors.<ref>{{harvnb|Rutherford| August 1917|pp=14,15}}</ref> Between August and November the society and the four ousted directors published a series of pamphlets, with each side accusing the other of ambitious and reckless behavior. The former directors also claimed Rutherford had required all headquarters workers to sign a petition supporting him and threatened dismissal for any who refused to sign.<ref>{{harvnb|Pierson et al| 1917|p=9}}</ref> The former directors left the Brooklyn headquarters on August 8.<ref name="Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society 1993 p=68">{{harvnb|Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society| 1993|p=68}}</ref> On January 5, 1918, shareholders returned Rutherford to office.
The controversy fractured the Bible Student movement and some congregations split into opposing groups loyal either to Rutherford or those he had expelled.<ref name="Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society 1993 p=68"/><ref>''Proclaimers of God's Kingdom'' (1993) identifies opposing sides as "those loyal to the Society and those who were easy prey to the smooth talk of the opposers" (p. 68). ''Yearbook of Jehovah's Witnesses'' (1975) dismisses the four ousted directors as "rebellious individuals who claimed to be board members" (p. 87) and men who "ambitiously sought to gain administrative control of the Society" (p. 92).</ref> By mid-1919 about one in seven Bible Students had chosen to leave rather than accept Rutherford's leadership,<ref>{{harvnb|Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society|1975|pp=93–94}}</ref> and over the following decade they helped form or joined other groups including the Stand Fast Movement, the [[Layman's Home Missionary Movement]], the [[Dawn Bible Students Association]], the [[Pastoral Bible Institute]], the Elijah Voice Movement, the [[Concordant Publishing Concern]], and the Eagle Society.<ref>{{harvnb|Rogerson|1969|p=39}}</ref>
==''The Finished Mystery''==
In late 1916 Fisher and another prominent Bible Student at the Brooklyn headquarters, Clayton J. Woodworth, sought the Executive Committee's approval to produce a book about the prophecies of the books of [[Book of Revelation|Revelation]] and [[Book of Ezekiel|Ezekiel]] based primarily on Russell's writings.<ref>{{harvnb|Wills|2007|p=97}}</ref> Work on the book, ''The Finished Mystery'', proceeded without the knowledge of the full Board of Directors and Editorial Committee<ref>{{harvnb|Pierson et al|1917|p=11}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Jehovah's Witnesses in the Divine Purpose|publisher=Watchtower|year=1959|page=70}}</ref> and was released by Rutherford to headquarters staff on July 17, 1917, the day he announced the appointment of the four replacement directors. [[File:Scan of the cover for "The Finished Mystery" - published in the United States in 1917.png|thumb|left|"The Finished Mystery"—vol. 7 of "Studies in the Scriptures"]] The book, which was misleadingly labeled as the posthumous seventh volume of Russell's ''Studies in the Scriptures'',<ref>[https://archive.org/details/americanstatetr00howagoog Lawson, John D., ''American State Trials'', vol 13, Thomas Law Book Company, 1921], p. viii: "After his death and after we were in the war they issued a seventh volume of this series, entitled "The Finished Mystery," which, under the guise of being a posthumous work of Pastor Russell, included an attack on the war and an attack on patriotism, which were not written by Pastor Russell and could not have possibly been written by him."</ref><ref>Crompton, Robert. ''Counting the Days to Armageddon''. Cambridge: James Clarke & Co. 1996. pp 84–85: "One of Rutherford's first actions as president ... was, without reference either to his fellow directors or to the editorial committee which Russell had nominated in his will, to commission a seventh volume of Studies in the Scriptures. Responsibility for preparing this volume was given to two of Russell's close associates, George H. Fisher and Clayton J. Woodworth. On the face of it, their brief was to edit for publication the notes left by Russell ... and to draw upon his published writings ... It is obvious ... that it was not in any straightforward sense the result of editing Russell's papers, rather it was in large measure the original work of Woodworth and Fisher at the behest of the new president."</ref> was denounced by Rutherford's opponents, but became a best-seller and was translated into six languages and serialized in ''The Watch Tower''.<ref name="Rogerson 1969 p=40">{{harvnb|Rogerson|1969|p=40}}</ref> Expecting [[Kingdom of God|God's Kingdom]] to establish rule on earth and for the saints to be raised to heaven in 1918,<ref name="Rogerson 1969 p=40"/> Rutherford wrote in January of that year: "The Christian looks for the year to bring the full consummation of the church's hopes."<ref>''Watch Tower'', October 1, 1917, January 1, 1918.</ref> He embarked on a vast advertising campaign to expose the "unrighteousness" of religions and their alliances with "beastly" governments, expanding on claims in ''The Finished Mystery'' that patriotism was a delusion and murder.<ref>{{harvnb|Wills|2007|p=100}}</ref><ref name="Rogerson 1969 41">{{harvnb|Rogerson|1969|p=41}}</ref> The campaign attracted the attention of governments and on February 12, 1918 the book was banned by the [[Canadian government]] for what a [[Winnipeg]] newspaper described as "seditious and antiwar statements"<ref name="Macmillan 1957 p=85">{{harvnb|Macmillan|1957|p=85}}</ref> On February 24 in [[Los Angeles]] Rutherford gave a talk entitled "The World Has Ended—Millions Now Living May Never Die" (subsequent talks in the series were renamed, "Millions Now Living ''Will'' Never Die")<ref>The initial delivery was entitled "The World Has Ended—Millions Now Living May Never Die". See:<br />"Noteworthy Events in the Modern-day History of Jehovah's Witnesses", ''Jehovah's Witnesses – Proclaimers of God's Kingdom"'', 1993 Watch Tower, p. 719, "1918 The discourse "The World Has Ended—Millions Now Living May Never Die" is first delivered, on February 24, in Los Angeles, California. On March 31, in Boston, Massachusetts, the talk is entitled "The World Has Ended—Millions Now Living Will Never Die" [emphasis added]</ref><ref>''Los Angeles Morning Tribune'', February 25, 1918, as recorded in ''Faith on the March'' by A. H. Macmillan, 1957, p. 86</ref> in which he attacked the [[Clergy#Christianity|clergy]], declaring: "As a class, according to the Scriptures, the clergymen are the most reprehensible men on earth for [[World War I|the great war]] that is now afflicting mankind."<ref name="Macmillan 1957 p=85"/> Three days later the [[Military Intelligence Corps (United States Army)|Army Intelligence Bureau]] seized the Society's Los Angeles offices and confiscated literature.
===Imprisonment and release=== In early May 1918 [[United States Attorney General|US Attorney General]] [[Thomas Watt Gregory]] condemned ''The Finished Mystery'' as "one of the most dangerous examples of ... propaganda ... a work written in extremely religious language and distributed in enormous numbers".<ref>{{harvnb|Macmillan|1957|p=89}}</ref> Warrants were issued for the arrest of Rutherford and seven other Watch Tower directors, who were charged under the [[Espionage Act of 1917|1917 Espionage Act]] of attempting to cause insubordination, disloyalty, refusal of duty in the armed forces and obstructing the recruitment and enlistment service of the U.S. while it was at war.<ref name="Rogerson 1969 41"/> On June 21 seven of them, including Rutherford, were sentenced to 20 years' imprisonment. Rutherford feared his opponents would gain control of the Society in his absence, but on January 2, 1919 he learned he had been re-elected president at the Pittsburgh convention the day before, convincing him that God wanted him in the position.<ref>{{harvnb|Macmillan|1957|p=106}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Macmillan|1957|pp=105,106}}</ref> In March 1919 the directors were released on bail after an appeals court ruled they had been wrongly convicted; in May 1920 the government announced that all charges had been dropped.<ref name="Rogerson 1969 44">{{harvnb|Rogerson|1969|p=44}}</ref>
==Reorganization==
===Administrative changes===
Following his release from prison, Rutherford began a major reorganization of Bible Student activities. At a May, 1919 convention in [[Ohio]] he announced the publication of a new magazine, ''The Golden Age'' (later renamed ''[[Awake!]]''). Because Russell's [[Last Will and Testament|will]] had decreed the Society should publish no other periodicals<ref name="Penton 1997 p=56">{{harvnb|Penton|1997|p=56}}</ref> the new magazine was at first published by "Woodworth, Hudgings & Martin", with a Manhattan (rather than Brooklyn) address.<ref>''The Golden Age'', volume 1, number 1, October 1, 1919, cover, [http://www.strictlygenteel.co.uk/goldenage/ga1919.html As Retrieved 2010-02-16]</ref> Within months Bible Students were organized to distribute it door-to-door.<ref name="Penton 1997 p=56"/> He expanded the Society's printing facilities, revived the colporteur work and in 1920 introduced the requirement for weekly reports of Bible Students' preaching activity.<ref>{{harvnb|Rogerson|1969|pp=53,54}}</ref><ref>"Annual report for 1920", ''The Watchtower'', December 15, 1920, "At the beginning of the fiscal year there were only 225 active colporteurs in the field. The number has now increased to 350, all of whom are devoting their entire time to the service ... In addition to the colporteurs there are reported to this office 8,052 class workers."</ref> He expanded and reorganized overseas branch offices<ref name="Penton 1997 p=57">{{harvnb|Penton|1997|p=57}}</ref> in what he regarded as a "cleansing" and "sifting" work.<ref>{{harvnb|Rogerson|1969|pp=52,53}}</ref>
[[File:Joseph Franklin Rutherford 3.jpg|thumb|right| J.F. Rutherford]]Beginning with an eight-day convention at [[Cedar Point]], [[Ohio]], in September 1922 Rutherford, launched a series of major international conventions under the theme "Advertise the King and Kingdom", attracting crowds of up to 20,000.<ref>{{harvnb|Rogerson|1969|p=54}}</ref> Audiences were urged to "herald the message far and wide".<ref>{{harvnb|Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society|1975|p=131}}</ref> He stressed that the primary duty of all Bible Students was to become "publicity agents" in fulfillment of Matthew 24:14, especially in the form of door-to-door evangelism with the Society's publications.<ref name="Penton 1997 60">{{harvnb|Penton|1997|p=60}}</ref><ref>Watchtower March 1, 1925 p. 72 col 2</ref> In 1928 Rutherford began to teach that the Cedar Point convention and the events resulting from it fulfilled the prophecy of the 1290 days at Daniel 12:11.<ref>Watchtower December 15, 1929 pp 371–77: "Briefly, then, these prophecies and the dates of their fulfilment {{sic}} are as follows, to wit: The fixed "time of the end" is October 1, 1914 A.D. The 1260-day period ended in April, 1918. The 1290-day period ended September, 1922. The 1335-day period of blessedness began May, 1926, and goes on for ever."</ref><ref>The Harp of God, 1928 edition</ref>
In 1920, Rutherford published a booklet, ''Millions Now Living Will Never Die'', and a year later published his first hardcover book, ''The Harp of God''. This was followed by a further nineteen hardcover books, each with one-word titles, such as ''Creation'' (1927), ''Jehovah'' (1934) and ''Children'' (1941). His publications reached a total printing of 36 million copies.<ref>{{harvnb|Penton|1997|p=58}}</ref> In 1925 he gained full control over what doctrines would be taught in Watch Tower Society publications, overruling the refusal by the five-man Editorial Committee to publish his article, "Birth of the Nation",<ref>''Watchtower'', March 1, 1925 pp 67–74. In the content list on the cover the article is entitled ''Birth of '''a''' Nation'', but the article itself on page 67 is entitled ''Birth of '''the''' Nation''</ref> which contained significant doctrinal changes.<ref>{{harvnb|Penton|1997|p=59}}</ref> Rutherford later claimed [[Satan]] had "tried to prevent the publication of that article ... but failed in that effort";<ref name="Watchtower, July 1, 1938, p. 201">''Watchtower'', July 1, 1938, p. 201.</ref> In 1927 the Watch Tower Society ceased printing of Russell's ''Studies in the Scriptures''.<ref>WTB&TS, "God's Kingdom of a Thousand Years Has Approached" (1973) p. 347</ref> The Editorial Committee was dissolved in 1931, after which Rutherford wrote every leading article in ''The Watch Tower'' until his death.<ref>{{harvnb|Wills|2006|p=121}}</ref> The 1933 Watch Tower Society ''Yearbook'' observed that the demise of the Editorial Committee indicated "that the Lord himself is running his organization".<ref>''Yearbook'', Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society, 1933, p. 11.</ref>
Rutherford expanded his means of spreading the Watch Tower message in 1924 with the start of 15-minute radio broadcasts, initially from WBBR, based on [[Staten Island]], and eventually via a network of as many as 480 radio stations.<ref name="Rogerson 1969 55">{{harvnb|Rogerson|1969|p=55}}</ref> A 1931 talk was broadcast throughout North America, Australia and France, but his attacks on the clergy resulted in both the [[NBC]] and [[British Broadcasting Corporation|BBC]] radio networks banning his broadcasts.<ref>{{harvnb|Wills|pp=149–151}}</ref>
In 1928 Rutherford began to abolish the system of electing elders by congregational voting, dismissing them as "haughty" and "lazy", and finally asserting in 1932 that electing elders was unscriptural.<ref>{{harvnb|Penton|p=64}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Wills|2006|pp=177–179}}</ref> He impressed on elders the need to obey the Society's "regulations", "instructions" and "directions" without complaint.<ref>{{harvnb|Wills|2006|p=176}}</ref> Service directors, who reported back to Brooklyn, were appointed in each congregation and a weekly "[[Jehovah's Witnesses practices#Midweek meeting|service meeting]]" introduced to meeting programs.<ref>{{harvnb|Wills|2006|p=175}}</ref> In 1933 Rutherford claimed that abolishing elective elders was a fulfillment of the prophecy of 2300 days at Daniel 8:13–14, and that God's sanctuary (the Watch Tower Society) was thereby cleansed.<ref>Watchtower July 15, 1933 pp. 214-15: "Beginning to count from the transgression resulting by reason of the League of Nations, and the giving of notice, which must begin May 25, 1926, the twenty-three hundred days, or six years, four months, and twenty days, would end October 15, 1932...What, then, took place at the end of the twenty-three-hundred-day period? ''The Watchtower'', issues of August 15 and September 1, 1932, brought before God's people the Scriptural proof that the office of "elective elder", chosen or selected by vote of creatures, does not Scripturally exist, and that therefore the selection of elders by such means should end." In 1971 the Watchtower Society changed the interpretation ending the 2300 days in 1944 rather than 1932.</ref>
At a 1931 Bible Student assembly in [[Columbus, Ohio]] Rutherford proposed a new name for the organization, ''Jehovah's witnesses'', to differentiate them from the proliferation of other groups that followed Russell's teachings.<ref name="Rogerson 1969 55"/> Bible Students who opposed or abandoned Rutherford to form new groups were increasingly described as the "evil servant class" by ''The Watchtower'', which said it was wrong to pray for those who were "unfaithful".<ref>{{harvnb|Wills|2006|pp=167–172}}</ref><ref>''Watchtower'', February 15, 1933.</ref> Four years later the term "Kingdom Hall" was introduced for the local meeting place of congregations.<ref>''Jehovah's Witnesses – Proclaimers of God's Kingdom'' chap. 20 p. 319, 721</ref>
In 1937, the door-to-door preaching program was extended to formally include "back calls" on interested people and Witnesses were urged to start one-hour [[Organizational structure of Jehovah's Witnesses#Students|Bible studies]] in the homes of householders.<ref name="Rogerson 1969 57"/><ref>"Testing and Sifting in Modern Times", ''The Watchtower'', June 15, 1987, p. 18.</ref> In the late 1930s, he advocated the use of "sound cars" and portable [[phonograph]]s with which talks by Rutherford were played to passersby and householders.<ref name="Rogerson 1969 57">{{harvnb|Rogerson|1969|p=57}}</ref>
In 1938 he introduced the term "theocracy" to describe the denomination's system of government, with ''Consolation'' explaining: "The Theocracy is at present administered by the Watch Tower Bible and Tract Society, of which Judge Rutherford is the president and general manager."<ref>''Consolation'', September 4, 1940, p. 25, as cited by Penton, p. 61.</ref> "Zone servants" (now known as ''[[Organizational structure of Jehovah's Witnesses#Circuit|circuit overseers]]'') were appointed to supervise congregations. In a ''Watchtower'' article Rutherford declared the need for congregations to "get in line" with the changed structure.<ref>{{harvnb|Wills|2006|p=201}}</ref><ref>''Watchtower'', June 15, 1938.</ref>
By 1942, the year of his death, worldwide attendance at the annual [[Jehovah's Witnesses practices#Memorial of Christ's death|Memorial of Christ's death]] was 140,450 though his restructuring of the Bible Student community coincided with a dramatic loss of followers during the 1920s and 1930s. Worldwide attendance of the annual Memorial of Christ's death fell from 90,434 in 1925<ref>{{harvnb|Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society|1959|p=110}}</ref> to 17,380 in 1928.<ref name="Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society 1959 312–313">{{harvnb|Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society|1959|pp=312–313}}</ref> Memorial attendance figures did not surpass 90,000 again until 1940.<ref name="Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society 1959 312–313"/> Author Tony Wills, who analyzed attendance and "field worker" statistics, suggests it was the "more dedicated" Bible Students who quit through the 1920s, to be replaced by newcomers in larger numbers, although Rutherford dismissed the loss of the original Bible Students as the Lord "shaking out" the unfaithful.<ref>{{harvnb|Wills|2007|pp=142, 146, 157–159}}</ref><ref>1931 Yearbook, Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society, p. 57.</ref> In the ''1942 Yearbook of Jehovah's Witnesses'', Rutherford wrote that the year's achievements "would, on the face of it, show that the Theocratic witness work on earth is about done".<ref name="Wills 2007 p=223"/><ref>''Yearbook'', 1942, Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society, p. 29.</ref>
===Doctrinal changes===
In July 1917, Rutherford had ''The Finished Mystery'' published as a seventh volume of the ''Studies in the Scriptures'' series. The volume, though written by Fisher and Woodworth, was advertised as Russell's "posthumous work" and "last legacy"<ref>''The Finished Mystery'', 1917, p. 2: "POSTHUMOUS WORK OF PASTOR RUSSELL His Last Legacy to the Dear Israel of God (Matt. 20:9)"</ref><ref>''The Bible Students Monthly'', December 1917, vol. 9 no. 9, p. 1: "The following article is extracted mainly from Pastor Russell's posthumous volume entitled "THE FINISHED MYSTERY," the 7th in the series of his STUDIES IN THE SCRIPTURES and published subsequent to his death... In this posthumous volume, which is called his "last legacy to the Christians of earth" is found a thorough exposition of every verse in the entire Book of Revelation."</ref> but contained several interpretations and viewpoints not espoused by Russell,<ref>Tony Mills, ''A People for His Name'', 2007, pp 97–8: "While he keeps faithfully to Russell's comments in most cases, there are a few times when he goes beyond Russell's plainly stated interpretation. In some of the chapters of Revelation on which Russell left no comments his imagination wandered free. He ridicules John Wesley, whom Russell admired, and his Methodist movement. He calls Europeans "the most cruel, bloodthirsty, quarrelsome, rapacious people on earth," a thought Russell denied. He ridicules Calvinists by saying that they have "lost their manhood, reason and common sense." He ridicules politics, patriotism, religion and almost everything the world holds holy, without (as Russell was careful to do) presenting the good along with the bad."</ref><ref>Bible Students Tract Society, ''Notes and Comments on the Finished Mystery'', Feb. 1919, pp 6–7: "Thus we have Bro. Woodworth's distinct statement that none of these interpretations of Revelation are Pastor Russell's, but another's {{sic}} (presumably his own)... Have Pastor Russell's interpretations been followed? To this we reply that in many cases they have not. On the contrary, entirely contradictory ones are frequently given."</ref> including an urging of all Bible Students to cast judgment upon Christendom and its clergy, the adoption of new dates for the fulfillment of particular prophecies, a claim that salvation is tied to membership within the Watch Tower Society, as well as shunning and censuring any who reject the interpretations given in the volume or related articles in ''Zion's Watch Tower'' magazine.
[[File:Mnlwnd.png|thumb|right|"Millions Now Living Will Never Die" contains some of the earliest doctrinal changes]][[File:1920 Rutherford NationalTheatre BostonEveningGlobe Dec17.png|thumb|right|Newspaper advertisement for Rutherford's "Millions" lecture.]]In the February 1918 discourse "Millions Now Living Will Never Die" (printed in booklet form in May 1920) a revision of Russell's calculation of a "Jubilee type" was presented, changing it from 1875 to 1925,<ref>''The Time is at Hand'', 1889, p. 183: "Reckoned from the beginning of the seventy years desolation under Babylon, the great cycle [50x50] ends with the year A.D. 1875."</ref><ref>''Millions Now Living Will Never Die!'', 1920, p.88 : "A simple calculation of these jubilees brings us to this important fact: Seventy jubilees of fifty years each would be a total of 3500 years. That period of time beginning 1575 before A.D. 1 of necessity would end in the fall of the year 1925."</ref> despite Russell's rejection of such a change a few months prior to his death.<ref>''The Watch Tower'' April 15, 1916 p. 127: "We cannot help it that many of the dear friends continue to tell what THE WATCH TOWER believes, and to misrepresent its teachings. Our kindest thought must be that they are not giving much heed to its teachings. Otherwise they would know from its columns that we are not looking forward to 1925, nor to any other date. As expressly stated in THE WATCH TOWER, we are simply going on, our last date or appointment having been passed more than a year ago...we have no different time in mind from the Scriptures on the subject and do not expect to have any."</ref> In October 1920 the Society published a new edition of Russell's 1881 ''Tabernacle Shadows of the Better Sacrifices''. It included an appendix introducing many alterations or reinterpretations of Russell's original views on the death of Jesus and the role of Christ's followers in heaven as typified in the ceremonies of the Jewish tabernacle.<ref>Tabernacle Shadows of the Better Sacrifices, 1920, ''Appendix of Notes'' pp 133–155: "Thirty-nine years have passed since the publication of this little booklet; and during that time some of the teachings herein contained have come to be seen in clearer light – even as the details of a mountain become more discernible the closer one draws to it. In harmony with these clearer understandings we suggest the following alterations in appendix form, leaving the text intact out of deference to the honored and beloved writer of the booklet."</ref>
At the 1922 Cedar Point convention Rutherford began teaching that Christ's reign had begun in 1914,<ref>''Watchtower'', December 15, 1922, p. 394.</ref> and not 1878 as Russell had taught.<ref>[http://www.mostholyfaith.com/bible/Reprints/Z1881JAN.asp "How Long, O Lord?", ''Zion's Watch Tower'', January 1881.]</ref> Rutherford expanded on this view in the March 1, 1925 issue of ''The Watch Tower'' in the article "Birth of The Nation", which he later acknowledged "caused a real stir or shake-up within the ranks."<ref name="Watchtower, July 1, 1938, p. 201"/> In 1927 he moved the date of the resurrection of the "sleeping saints" (all Christians who had died since Jesus' time) from 1878 to 1918<ref>Watchtower June 1, 1927 p. 166.</ref><ref>[http://www.strictlygenteel.co.uk/light1/light1_6.html ''Light'' by J. F. Rutherford, Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society, 1930, p 226.]</ref> and as early as 1930 began to dismiss the year 1874 as the date for the invisible presence of Christ in favor of the year 1914.<ref>''The Golden Age'' May 7, 1930 p. 503</ref><ref>''The Golden Age'' March 14, 1934 p 380 "Prior to 1914 and years thereafter we thought that our Lord's return dated from 1874; and we took it for granted that the ''parousia'' or presence of our Lord dated from that time. An examination of the scriptures containing the word parousia shows that the presence of the Lord could not date prior to 1914."</ref>
From 1925 he developed the view of the battle of [[Armageddon]] as a universal war waged by God rather than Russell's belief that it was the decline of human society into social, political and religious anarchy. Rutherford based his interpretations on the books of [[Book of Exodus|Exodus]], [[Book of Jeremiah|Jeremiah]], [[Book of Ezekiel|Ezekiel]] and [[Psalms]] as well as additional material from the books of [[Book of Samuel|Samuel]], [[Books of Kings|Kings]] and [[Books of Chronicles|Chronicles]].<ref>{{harvnb|Wills|2007|pp=154,155}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Rogerson|1969|p=47}}</ref><ref>"Can This World's Armageddon Be Avoided?", ''Watchtower'', December 1, 1966, p. 730.</ref> An article in the January 1, 1926 ''Watch Tower'' introduced new emphasis on the importance of the name "Jehovah";<ref>{{harvnb|Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society|1993|p=124}}</ref> from 1929 Rutherford taught that the vindication of God's name—which would ultimately occur when millions of unbelievers were destroyed at Armageddon—was the primary doctrine of Christianity and more important than God's display of goodness or grace toward humankind.<ref>{{harvnb|Wills|2007|pp=181, 182}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Penton|1997|p=69}}</ref><ref>[http://www.strictlygenteel.co.uk/prophecy/prophecy12.html J.F. Rutherford, ''Prophecy'', Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society, 1929, pp. 319, 328–333]</ref><ref>[http://www.strictlygenteel.co.uk/vindication1/vindication1_1.html J.F. Rutherford, ''Vindication'', Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society, 1931, pp. 9–14, 65–68, 135.]</ref> In 1932 he published an interpretation of a passage in Ezekiel describing the attack on Jerusalem by [[Gog and Magog|Gog of Magog]], in which he predicted an intensification of persecution of Jehovah's Witnesses that would culminate in God intervening on their behalf to begin the battle of Armageddon, which would destroy all opposers of God's organization.<ref name="Wills 2007 p=223">{{harvnb|Wills|2007|p=223}}</ref>
In 1926 he discredited Russell's teaching on the importance of Christian "character development" or personal "sanctification"<ref name="Penton 1997 60"/><ref>{{harvnb|Wills|2007|p=143}}</ref><ref>"Character or Covenant – Which?", ''The Watchtower'', May 1, 1926</ref> and a year later discarded the teaching that Russell had been the "faithful and wise servant" of Matthew 24:45–47, warning that the desire to revere men was a snare set by the [[Devil#Christianity|Devil]].<ref name="Penton 1997 60"/><ref>''Watchtower'', January 1, 1927, p. 7.</ref> In May 1926 Rutherford released his book ''Deliverance'' at the Bible Student's convention in [[Kensington]], England later interpreting the event as the fulfillment of the 1335 days of Daniel 12:12.<ref>Watchtower July 15, 1933 p. 214 col 2</ref>
In 1927, Christmas was declared to be of pagan origin, and the following year its celebration by Bible Students was condemned as supporting "Satan's organization".<ref>''The Golden Age'', December 14, 1927, "The Origin of Christmas", pp 178–79</ref><ref>''1975 Yearbook of Jehovah's Witnesses'', 1974, p. 147</ref> Mother's Day was condemned in 1931,<ref>''Vindication'' book 1, 1931, pp 158–60: "On the face of it the arrangement of "Mother's Day" seems harmless and calculated to do good. But the people are in ignorance of Satan's subtle hand in the matter, and that he is back of the movement, to turn the people away from God... Neither the man nor the woman should be worshiped for doing right, because such doing of right is their duty. Creature worship of any kind is wrong and an abomination in the sight of God."</ref> with other holidays as well as birthdays officially renounced in subsequent years.<ref>George Chryssides, ''Historical Dictionary of Jehovah's Witnesses'', 2008, p. 21</ref><ref>''Jehovah's Witnesses: Proclaimers of God's Kingdom'', 1993, p. 199</ref>
In 1928 Rutherford discarded Russell's teaching that the natural Jews would be restored to Palestine and return to God's favor, despite having declared ten years earlier that prophecies of their restoration were already being fulfilled with the [[British Mandate for Palestine (legal instrument)|British takeover of Palestine]] from [[Turkey]] during [[World War I]].<ref>{{harvnb|Wills|2007|p=38}}</ref> He denied there was a role for Jews in God's Kingdom arrangement and by 1933 he had reversed Russell's earlier teaching, claiming that prominent Jewish business leaders were "arrogant, self-important and extremely selfish," and would gain no favored standing with God.<ref>J. F. Rutherford, ''Favored People'', Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society, as cited by Wills, 2007, p. 129.</ref> The teaching that God would restore the Jews to Palestine was discontinued around the same time.<ref>{{harvnb|Rogerson|1969|p=46}}</ref>
Russell's teaching that the [[Great Pyramid of Giza]] was built under God's direction<ref>{{Citation|title=Thy Kingdom Come|pages=309–376|url=http://www.pastor-russell.com/volumes/V3/Study_10.html}}</ref> was overturned in 1928, when Rutherford asserted that it had been built under the direction of Satan for the purpose of deceiving God's people in the last days.<ref>The Messenger, August 5, 1928 p. 1: "When the Lord spoke of hiding his people in his secret place he was not talking about any chambers in the pyramid, built by the Devil himself."</ref><ref>The Watch Tower, November 15, 1928</ref> The announcement prompted further defections among long-time Bible Students.<ref>Great Pyramid Passages, 1924, reprint by Portland Area Bible Students, 1988, pp i–xxxviii</ref><ref>The Messenger, August 5, 1928 p. 2: "It sure did set the tongues wagging at the Fair Grounds and resulted in another overhauling of the old trunk wherein are kept a few choice relics of what, until recently, we honestly believed the Bible teaches."</ref>
In 1930, Rutherford published a systematic reinterpretation of the book of Revelation.<ref>''Light'' book 1 and 2, 1930</ref> Many of the symbols recorded in the book were applied to events following 1918, specifically to Watch Tower conventions held in the years 1922 through 1928.<ref>''Light'' book 1, 1930, p. 106</ref> These reinterpretations reflected both a wholesale rejection of his own earlier views as well as the [[Historicism (Christianity)|historicist]] interpretations of Pastor Russell.<ref>''The Finished Mystery'', 1917</ref><ref>Gruss, p. 172</ref><ref>''The Watch Tower'', Nov 15, 1916, p. 343</ref>
At a [[Washington, D.C.]] convention in 1935, Rutherford rejected Russell's teaching that the "great company" of Revelation 7:9 was a "secondary spiritual class" composed of millions of Christians who would be resurrected to heaven apart from the [[144,000#Jehovah's Witnesses|144,000 "elect"]], and instead argued that the "[[Jehovah's Witnesses and salvation#The 'other sheep' and the 'great crowd'|great multitude]]", the "sheep" of Matthew 25 and the "[[Jehonadab|Jonadabs]]" of [[2 Kings]] chapter 10 all picture the people who could potentially survive Armageddon and receive everlasting human life on earth if they became Jehovah's Witnesses before it began.<ref name="Penton 1997 72">{{harvnb|Penton|1997|p=72}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society|1959|p=140}}</ref>
In 1935, Rutherford objected to U.S. state laws requiring school students to [[Pledge of Allegiance (United States)|salute the flag]] as a means of instilling patriotism; in the 1936 ''Yearbook'' he declared that baptized Jehovah's Witnesses who did [[flag salute|salute]] the [[National flag|flag]] were breaking their covenant with God and were thus "guilty of death".<ref>''Yearbook'', 1936, p. 22, "The saluting of or salutation to a flag means this: 'I depend on what the flag represents for my salvation. Those who know and serve God in spirit and in truth look to Jehovah God for salvation, and not to any man or any man-made organization. It therefore follows that the saluting of any flag by those who are in covenant with Jehovah God to do his will constitutes the breaking of that covenant with God, and such covenant breakers are guilty of death."</ref> In 1940, children in 43 states were expelled for refusing to salute the flag and the Watch Tower Society took most cases to court, with Rutherford personally leading the unsuccessful case of [[Minersville School District v. Gobitis]]. Controversy over the flag salute issue escalated and mob attacks became prevalent in many U.S. states until 1943 when the court overruled its previous decision in the case of [[West Virginia State Board of Education v. Barnette]].<ref>{{harvnb|Wills|2007|pp=214–224}}</ref> A U.S. law magazine noted how Jehovah's Witnesses had helped shape the course of constitutional law, remarking: "Through almost constant litigation this organization had made possible an ever-increasing list of precedents concerning the application of the [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|14th amendment]] to freedom of speech and religion".<ref>''American Bar Association's Bill of Rights Review'', Vol 2, No.4, Summer 1942, p. 262.</ref>
In 1936, Rutherford rejected the belief that Jesus had been executed on a Roman cross, in favor of an upright stake or "tree."<ref>''Riches'', 1936, p. 27: "Jesus was crucified, not on a cross of wood, such as is exhibited in many images and pictures, and which images are made and exhibited by men; Jesus was crucified by nailing his body to a tree."</ref>
==Character and attitudes== [[File:Judge Rutherford Cadillac.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Rutherford with [[Cadillac V-16]] from the Watchtower publication ''The Messenger'' (1931)]]Biographers describe Rutherford as tall and solidly built with a senatorial demeanor,<ref>Herbert H. Stroup, ''The Jehovah's Witnesses'', Columbia University Press, 1945, p. 16.</ref> and a strong booming voice that helped make him a powerful orator.<ref>{{harvnb|Penton|1997|p=47}}</ref><ref name="Wills 2007 131">{{harvnb|Wills|2007|p=131}}</ref> In 1917, ''The New York Times'' stated that Rutherford "has a reputation as an eloquent, forceful speaker".<ref name=timesjudge /> Watch Tower Society literature states that his personality contrasted strongly with that of his predecessor. One Witness history book says that while Russell was kind, warm and tactful, Rutherford "was warm and generous toward his associates but he was also a brusque and direct type of person, and his legal background and experiences in early life gave him a directness in his approach to problems in dealing with his brothers that caused some to take offense."<ref>{{harvnb|Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society|1959|pp=68, 69}}</ref> Another Watch Tower Society account says he did not hide his feelings, adding, "His bluntness, even when spoken in kindness, was sometimes misunderstood."<ref>{{harvnb|Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society|1975|p=83}}</ref> Fellow Watch Tower Society director A. H. Macmillan says Rutherford "spoke as simply and directly to the people as he knew how, and he was an extremely forthright man. He was thoroughly convinced that what he had to say was the truth and that it was a matter of life and death."<ref>{{harvnb|Macmillan|1957|pp=150,151}}</ref> Macmillan added, "He would never tolerate anything that would be contrary to what he clearly understood the Bible to teach. He was so strict about that, he would permit nothing that would seem to show a compromise when it came to an issue of the truth."<ref name="Macmillan 1957 77">{{harvnb|Macmillan|1957|p=77}}</ref> Author Tony Wills describes him as charitable and generous, and says his sympathy for the poor and oppressed was exceeded only by his hatred for the rich, the oppressors.<ref name="Wills 2007 131"/> Wills also notes that he was a dynamic, impatient [[Extraversion and introversion|extrovert]].<ref>{{harvnb|Wills|2007|p=107}}</ref> Other authors also address Rutherford's abrasiveness: James Penton describes him as blunt and moody with an explosive temper,<ref>P.S.L. Johnson's ''Harvest Siftings Reviewed'' (1917, p.17) relates an incident in which an enraged Rutherford rushed at him in a confrontation in Brooklyn Bethel, grabbed at his arm and "almost jerked me off my feet". Johnson complains that in an earlier hearing of complaints against him, Rutherford treated him to "sneers, sarcasm and ridicule. His face expressed more contempt than that of any other face upon which I have ever looked."(p.14)</ref> with "a streak of self-righteousness which caused him to regard anyone who opposed him as of the Devil",<ref>{{harvnb|Penton|1997|pp=47–48}}</ref> while Alan Rogerson notes that he was a "dogmatic and insensitive person, obsessed with his own self-importance."<ref>{{harvnb|Rogerson|1969|p=35}}</ref>
Rutherford's confrontation with four Watch Tower Society directors who opposed him in 1917 highlighted both the forcefulness of his personality and his determination to fight for what he believed was right. Penton claims Rutherford played "hard-fisted church politics"<ref>{{harvnb|Penton|1997|p=51}}</ref> and Rogerson accuses Rutherford of using ''The Watchtower'' as a propaganda medium to attack his opposers in what was effectively a battle for his position as president.<ref name="Rogerson 1969 p=37" /> At the heart of his opponents' complaints was his "autocratic" behavior as he strove to "exercise complete management of the Society and its affairs."<ref>{{harvnb|Pierson et al|1917|pp=3,4}}</ref> Penton similarly describes Rutherford's actions in his first year of presidency—including his appointment of new directors, refusal to allow the Society's accounts to be examined, and his unilateral decision to publish ''The Finished Mystery''—as high-handed and secretive.<ref>{{harvnb|Penton|1997|pp=51, 53}}</ref> In contrast, Rutherford claimed, "It was my duty to use the power the Lord had put into my hands to support the interests of the shareholders and all others interested in the Truth throughout the world ... to be unfaithful to them would be unfaithful to the Lord."<ref>{{harvnb|Rutherford|August 1917|p=17}}</ref> Macmillan, who supported Rutherford throughout the crisis, claimed the president was extremely patient and "did everything that he could to help his opposers see their mistake, holding a number of meetings with them, trying to reason with them and show them how contrary their course was to the Society's charter".<ref name="Macmillan 1957 77"/>
[[File:Judge Rutherford Uncovers Fifth Column (1940) - J.F. Rutherford.jpg|thumb|left|A 1940 Rutherford booklet "exposing" a Catholic campaign of mob violence against Jehovah's Witnesses]]According to Wills, Rutherford emerged from prison in 1919 bitter against the world and the collusion he saw between the clergy and military that had secured his imprisonment. Soon after his release he coined the term "Satan's organization" to refer to this supposed conspiracy.<ref>{{harvnb|Wills|2007|p=132}}</ref> In ''Watchtower'' articles Rutherford was similarly scathing towards [[big business]], politics and the [[League of Nations]].<ref>{{harvnb|Wills|2007|pp=131–138}}</ref> Rogerson describes Rutherford's attitude towards the clergy—his avowed enemies—as "unadulterated hatred".<ref name="Rogerson 1969 44"/> His attacks on clergymen, particularly those of the [[Catholic Church]], from the late 1920s were strong enough to attract a ban on his broadcasts by the [[NBC Radio Network|NBC radio network]], which condemned his "rabid attack upon organized religion and the clergy".<ref>''Yearbook'', 1930, p. 38</ref> He also applied criticizing terms to those who had deserted Watch Tower ranks, calling them the "evil servant".<ref>The term was drawn from the account of the "faithful servant" and "evil servant" of Matthew 24:45–51.</ref> He urged readers to view with contempt anyone who had "openly rebelled against God's order or commandments"<ref>''Watchtower'', February 15, 1933, p. 55.</ref> and also described elective elders of the 1930s who refused to submit to Watch Tower Society administrative changes as "despicable".<ref>''Watchtower'', March 15, 1938, p.87</ref>
Wills states that Rutherford seemed to relish his descriptions of how completely the wicked would be destroyed at Armageddon, dwelling at great length on prophecies of destruction. He claims that towards the close of his ministry Rutherford spent about half of each year's ''Watchtowers'' writing about Armageddon.<ref>{{harvnb|Wills|2007|p=154}}</ref>
According to Penton, Rutherford's austerity—evidenced by his distaste for [[Christmas]], [[birthday]] parties and other popular customs<ref>J.F.Rutherford, ''Vindication'', Vol I, pp. 188, 189, as cited by Wills, p. 139.</ref> that were described as of [[pagan]] origin or that encouraged [[creature worship]] and were not to be observed<ref>{{harvnb|Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society|1975|p=147}}</ref>—led in turn to austerity becoming a part of Witness life. In 1938, he directed that singing be dispensed with at congregation meetings;<ref name="Penton 1997 66">{{harvnb|Penton|1997|p=66}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society|1959|p=215}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society|1993|p=241}}, "singing in local congregations was largely dispensed with in about 1938"</ref><ref>''The Watchtower'', May 1, 1938, p 139, "At all study meetings...the one presiding at the study might well, as a prelude to the meeting, briefly state God's purpose which is now being performed... two minutes might well be devoted to such at the beginning of all meetings for study [by] the one presiding... A few words like the above pronounced at the beginning of the study would be far more beneficial than to occupy the same time in singing songs, which often express much that is out of harmony with the truth"</ref> singing was reinstated soon after his death.<ref>"Music's Place in Modern Worship", ''The Watchtower'', February 1, 1997, pp 26–27, "In 1938 singing at congregation meetings was largely dispensed with. However, the wisdom of following apostolic example and direction soon prevailed. At the 1944 district convention, F. W. Franz...announced the release of the ''Kingdom Service Song Book'' for use at the weekly service meetings."</ref>
Rutherford's books and magazine articles reveal his strong views on "[[Complementarianism|the proper place of women]]" in the church and society. In a 1931 book he linked the post-1919 rise of [[feminist movement|women's movements]] that encouraged equality of the sexes with satanic influence,<ref>J.F.Rutherford, ''Vindication'', Vol I, pp. 155–159, as cited by Wills, p. 139.</ref> and claimed the custom of men [[Hat tip|tipping their hats]] to women or standing when a woman approached was a scheme of the devil to turn men from God and indicated an effeminate streak in men who practiced the custom.<ref name="Penton 1997 66"/> [[Mother's Day]] was similarly described as part of a plan to turn people away from God.<ref>J.F.Rutherford, ''Vindication'', Vol I, pp. 155–157, as cited by Wills, p. 139.</ref> In 1938 he urged adherents to delay marriage and child-bearing until after Armageddon,<ref>''Watchtower'', November 15, 1938, p. 346.</ref> which Wills claims prompted a strong community bias among Witnesses against marriage. Those who did marry, says Wills, were considered to be weak in faith.<ref>{{harvnb|Wills|2007|p=138}}</ref> At a 1941 convention in Missouri he quoted [[Rudyard Kipling]]'s description of women as "a rag and a bone and a hank of hair".<ref name="Penton 1997 66"/><ref>[[Barbara Grizzuti Harrison]], ''Visions of Glory – A History and Memory of Jehovah's Witnesses'', Simon & Schuster, 1978, chapter 3.</ref>
Former Jehovah's Witness and former [[Governing Body of Jehovah's Witnesses|Governing Body]] member [[Raymond Franz]] claimed there was no evidence Rutherford engaged in door-to-door ministry despite his assertion that it was a requirement and sacred duty of all Witnesses. Franz claimed to have heard Rutherford's associates say his responsibilities as president "do not permit his engaging in this activity".<ref>Raymond Franz, ''In Search of Christian Freedom'', Commentary Press, 2007, pp. 191–192</ref> Macmillan, however, related details of Rutherford's home preaching in 1905 or 1906 when he was baptized,<ref>"Part 1—United States of America", ''1975 Yearbook of Jehovah's Witnesses'', 1975 Watch Tower, p 83</ref> and a 1975 article quoted several Witnesses relating their experiences with Rutherford in the house-to-house ministry in the 1920s.<ref>"Part 2—United States of America", ''1975 Yearbook of Jehovah's Witnesses'', 1975 Watch Tower, p 133</ref> The official history of Jehovah's Witnesses also notes, "Rutherford personally shared with other conventioners as they engaged in the work of Kingdom proclamation from house to house."<ref>"Conventions Proof of Our Brotherhood", ''Jehovah's Witnesses – Proclaimers of God's Kingdom'', 1993 Watch Tower, p 260</ref> On August 2, 1928 in a meeting with the Bible Student elders who had attended a general convention in [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]] Rutherford listed his responsibilities and concluded "when I have attended to many other details, I have not had very much time to go from door to door."<ref>''The Messenger'', August 3, 1928 p. 5: "Frequently some elder says: "The president of the Society does not go from house to house selling books. Why should I?" ... When I have looked after the management of the work at headquarters with its many departments; when I have given attention to a voluminous mail; when I have managed thirty odd branch offices in different parts of the earth and kept in close touch with them by correspondence and examination of their reports, and given advice and counsel as to what shall be done; when I have given attention to may {{sic}} legal matters that have arisen against members of the Society by reason of the opposition of the enemy; when I have given counsel to the various parts of the radio work; when I have prepared copy for The Watch Tower and other publications; and occasionally written a book or booklet and followed its progress through the manufacturing thereof; and when I have attended to many other details, I have not had very much time to go from door to door."</ref>
Authors William Whalen and James Penton have claimed that Rutherford was to Russell what [[Brigham Young]] was to [[Mormon]] prophet [[Joseph Smith]]. Penton contends that both Russell and Smith were capable religious leaders but naive visionaries, while Rutherford and Young were "hard-bitten pragmatists who gave a degree of permanency to the movements they dominated".<ref name="brigham">Prof. William J. Whalen, ''Armageddon Around the Corner: A report on Jehovah's Witnesses'', John Day, New York, 1962, page 67</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Penton|1997|pp=75–76}}</ref>
==Personal life==
[[File:Beth Sarim Outside Stairs.jpg|right|thumb|[[Beth Sarim]] was built in San Diego, California in 1929. Rutherford died at the property in 1942.]]Rutherford married Mary Malcolm Fetzer of Boonville, Missouri on December 31, 1891. Their only child, Malcolm Cleveland, was born on November 10, 1892.<ref>''St. Paul Enterprise'' January 16, 1917 p. 1</ref> The couple separated after Joseph Rutherford became president of the Watch Tower Society.<ref name="Penton 1997 72"/> Mary remained an active member of the Jehovah's Witnesses until becoming confined to her home in the years before her death in 1962 at age 93.<ref name=advertise89>"Advertise the King and the Kingdom! (1919–1941)", ''Jehovah's Witnesses – Proclaimers of God's Kingdom'', 1993 Watch Tower, p 89</ref>
Rutherford had reportedly lost the use of one lung from [[pneumonia]] suffered during his imprisonment in 1918 and 1919; finding New York's winter weather "impossible", Rutherford was encouraged by a doctor to "spend as much time as possible" in a more favorable climate.<ref>"Advertise the King and the Kingdom! (1919–1941)", ''Jehovah's Witnesses – Proclaimers of God's Kingdom'', 1993 Watch Tower, p 75</ref> In 1929, a residence named ''[[Beth Sarim]]'' (literally, ''House of Princes'') was constructed at [[San Diego, California]] for Rutherford's use,<ref>{{Citation|journal=The Messenger|title=Beth-Sarim – Much Talked About House|publisher=Watchtower|date=July 25, 1931|url=http://www.strictlygenteel.co.uk/tracts/1931_Messenger.pdf|pages=6, 8|postscript=.}} (17MB)</ref><ref>''1975 Yearbook of Jehovah's Witnesses'', 1974 Watch Tower, p 194, "In time, a direct contribution was made for the purpose of constructing a house in San Diego for Brother Rutherford's use."</ref> initially as winter accommodation and later as a full-time residence.<ref name=advertise89 /><ref>New York Times ''Deeds San Diego Home To Kings of Israel; Judge Rutherford in the Interim Occupies the House and Drives the Cars'' March 19, 1930 p. 31</ref> He died at the property in 1942. The villa was sold in 1948, with ''The Watchtower'' declaring, "It had fully served its purpose and was now only serving as a monument quite expensive to keep."<ref>''Watchtower'', December 15, 1947, as cited by ''Proclaimers'', 1993, p. 76.</ref>
The standard of Rutherford's accommodation and his personal conduct attracted criticism from some Bible Students and Jehovah's Witnesses in the 1930s. Walter F. Salter, the Society's former branch manager in Canada, wrote a public letter to Rutherford in 1937, the month he was expelled from the group, claiming that Rutherford had exclusive use of "luxurious" and "expensive" residences (in Brooklyn, Staten Island, Germany, and San Diego), as well as two [[Cadillac]]s<ref>{{harvnb|Penton|1997|pp=72,73}}</ref><ref>''The Watchtower'', May 15. 1937, p 159</ref><ref>''Jehovah's Witnesses and the Third Reich'' by M. James Penton, University of Toronto Press, 2004, p 368; though Salter's letter was dated "April 1, 1937", Penton writes, "Salter had broken with the Watch Tower Society and had been excommunicated from the Witness community at the time he wrote the letter."</ref> and alleged that on more than one occasion he had purchased for Rutherford cases of whiskey, brandy, beer and other liquors, and 'go from "drink to drink"'.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=h61sHeXTwXcC&pg=PA363 Letter to Rutherford by Walter Salter, reproduced in ''Jehovah's Witnesses and the Third Reich: sectarian politics under persecution'' by M. James Penton, University of Toronto Press, 2004, pp. 365-7.], "I, at your orders would purchase cases of whiskey at $60.00 a case, and cases of brandy and other liquors, to say nothing of untold cases of beer. A bottle or two of liquor would not do... [Rutherford] sends us out from door to door to face the enemy while he goes from 'drink to drink,' and tells us if we don't we are going to be destroyed."</ref> In July 1939 [[Olin R. Moyle]], legal counsel for the Society, wrote an open letter of resignation to the president, in which he complained about behavior of some members of the Watch Tower Society, including Rutherford himself, that he considered excessive and inappropriate. Moyle mentioned California when discussing "the difference between the accommodations furnished to you, and your personal attendants, compared with those furnished to some of your brethren." Moyle also accused Rutherford of "unkind treatment of the staff, outbursts of anger, discrimination and vulgar language" and condemned his allowing the "glorification of alcohol" at Bethel.<ref>[http://www.watchthetower.net/olin.html Moyle letter to Rutherford, July 21, 1939.]</ref><ref>{{Citation|title=A People For His Name: A History of Jehovah's Witnesses and an Evaluation|author=Tony Wills|pages=202–204|publisher=Lulu.com|year=2007|url=https://books.google.com/?id=iTt2EphfPr8C&pg=PA181 | isbn=978-1-4303-0100-4}}</ref><ref>Society directors defended Rutherford in an October 1939 ''Watchtower'' article, accusing Moyle of lies and "wicked slander" and claimed he was a "Judas" trying to cause division. Moyle successfully sued the board of directors for libel, collecting $15,000 plus court costs. See Penton, pp. 80–83 and Wills, pp. 202–205.</ref> Penton notes that Moyle was a "teetotaller" and "puritanical", but claims Rutherford's drinking habits were "notorious" and cites unnamed former Brooklyn Bethel workers who told of occasional difficulties in getting Rutherford to the podium to give public talks due to inebriation.<ref>{{harvnb|Penton|1997|pp=72,73}}: "Although Jehovah's Witnesses have done everything possible to hide accounts of the judge's drinking habits, they are simply too notorious to be denied. Former workers at the Watch Tower's New York headquarters recount tales of his inebriation and drunken stupors. Others tell stories of how difficult it sometimes was to get him to the podium to give talks at conventions because of his drunkenness. In San Diego, California, where he spent his winters from 1930 until his death, an elderly lady still speaks of how she sold him great quantities of liquor when he came to purchase medicines in her husband's drugstore."</ref>
==Death and burial== From the age of 70, Rutherford underwent several medical treatments for [[cancer of the colon]].<ref name="Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society 1993 89">{{harvnb|Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society|1993|p=89}}</ref> This included an operation on November 5, 1941, which found "carcinoma of the rectal sigmoid". Doctors gave him less than six months to live.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Rutherford died at Beth Sarim on January 8, 1942 at the age of 72.<ref>{{cite book | last = Rogerson |first = Alan| title = Millions Now Living Will Never Die: A Study of Jehovah's Witnesses | publisher = Constable & Co, London| year = 1969 |pages = 64| isbn = 0094559406}}</ref> Cause of death was "[[Uremia|uraemia]] due to carcinoma of the rectum due to pelvic metastasis."<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
A Watch Tower Society staff member said of the announcement of Rutherford's death, "It was at noontime when the family was assembled for lunch. ... The announcement was brief. There were no speeches. No one took the day off to mourn. Rather, we went back to the factory and worked harder than ever."<ref name="Watch Tower Bible & Tract Society 1993 89"/>
Rutherford's burial was delayed for five months<ref name="brigham" /> due to legal proceedings arising from his desire to be buried at Beth Sarim, which he had previously expressed to three close advisers from Brooklyn headquarters.<ref>{{Citation|title=Jehovah's Witnesses – Proclaimers of God's Kingdom|page=90}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|newspaper=The Evening Independent (St Petersburg, Florida)|date=January 26, 1942|title=Witnesses Ask Right To Bury Leader|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Zb4LAAAAIBAJ&sjid=KlUDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2083%2C1777860|page=18}}</ref> According to ''Consolation'', "Judge Rutherford looked for the early triumph of 'the King of the East', Christ Jesus, now leading the host of heaven, and he desired to be buried at dawn facing the rising sun, in an isolated part of the ground which would be administered by the princes, who should return from their graves."<ref>''Consolation'', May 27, 1942.</ref> Based on his claims that resurrected biblical characters would live at Beth Sarim, Rutherford concluded that it was appropriate that his bones be buried on the property.<ref>{{Citation|journal=Consolation|date=May 27, 1942}}</ref>
The legal problem arose because [[Beth Sarim]] was not a legally zoned [[cemetery]].<ref>{{harvnb|Penton|1997|p=74}}</ref> Witnesses collected more than 14,000 signatures for two petitions—one supporting his burial at Beth Sarim, another for a second preferred site on a nearby Watch Tower Society property named Beth-Shan—that Rutherford's dying wish might be granted.<ref>"San Diego officials line up against New Earth's princes", ''Consolation'', May 27, 1942, pp. 6,9</ref> ''Consolation'' condemned San Diego County officials for their refusal to grant a permit for Rutherford's burial at either property, stating "It was not the fate of the bones which they decided, but their own destiny. Nor is their blood on anyone else's head, because they were told three times that to fight against God, or to tamper with His servant's bones even, would bring upon them the condemnation of the Lord. ... So their responsibility is fixed, and they followed the course of Satan."<ref>{{Citation|newspaper=San Diego Union|title=No Will Left By Rutherford, Says Secretary|date=February 18, 1942}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|url=http://www.seanet.com/~raines/bethshan.html |title=Beth Shan—The Watchtower's "House of Security" |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081002170539/http://www.seanet.com/~raines/bethshan.html |archivedate=October 2, 2008 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Citation|url=http://www.equipresources.org/atf/cf/%7B9C4EE03A-F988-4091-84BD-F8E70A3B0215%7D/DJ566.pdf|title=Beth Shan and the Return of the Princes}}</ref>
Speculation that Rutherford was secretly buried at Beth Sarim has been called "private rumor", 'frequently disproven', and "myth".<ref>{{Citation|title=Witnesses of Jehovah|author=Leonard & Marjorie Chretien|publisher=Harvest House|year=1988|pages=49|isbn=0-89081-587-9}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|url=http://www.sandiegoreader.com/weblogs/bands/2008/jun/28/famous-dead-neighbors-in-san-diego-plus-my-brunch-/|title=San Diego Reader|date=June 28, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|title=Cemeteries of San Diego|author=Mallios|year=2007|publisher=Arcadia Publishing|pages=112|url=https://books.google.com/?id=-hNx2HsGxxgC&pg=PA103 | isbn=978-0-7385-4714-5|display-authors=etal}}</ref> The May 4, 1942 issue of ''[[Time magazine|Time]]'' magazine noted Rutherford's burial at [[Rossville, New York]], on [[Staten Island]];<ref>{{Citation|magazine=Time|title=Buried|date=May 4, 1942|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,777771,00.html}}</ref> a private burial plot for Watch Tower branch volunteers is on Woodrow Road.<ref>"Announcements", ''The Watchtower'', October 1, 1966, p 608</ref><ref>{{Citation|journal=Consolation|title=San Diego's Officials Line Up Against Earth's New Princes|date=May 27, 1942|pages=9, 14–16|publisher=Watchtower|format=}}</ref> In 2002, a caretaker at the immediately adjoining graveyard answered an inquiry about Watch Tower's graveyard by noting, "I couldn't tell you who is buried on it because it has absolutely no markers or headstones".<ref>{{Citation|last=Van Amburgh|first=W. E. |others=An enlarged replica of the International Bible Students Association's original 1924 book|title=The way to paradise|publisher=Lulu.com|year=2005|pages=45, 46|isbn=1-4116-5971-6|url=https://books.google.com/?id=9FkQjyYfsZAC&pg=RA1-PA45|accessdate=July 12, 2009}}</ref>
Rutherford was succeeded by [[Nathan Homer Knorr]] as president of the Watch Tower Society.
